Parsing [sent. 218 len. 17]: Happily I slipped away , and deposited that part of my conscience in my garret bedroom .
Parsing [sent. 219 len. 4]: `` Hark ! ''
Parsing [sent. 220 len. 36]: said I , when I had done my stirring , and was taking a final warm in the chimney corner before being sent up to bed ; `` was that great guns , Joe ? ''

Parsing [sent. 222 len. 3]: said Joe .

Parsing [sent. 224 len. 9]: `` What does that mean , Joe ? ''
Parsing [sent. 225 len. 19]: said I. Mrs. Joe , who always took explanations upon herself , said , snappishly , `` Escaped .
Parsing [sent. 226 len. 3]: Escaped . ''
Parsing [sent. 227 len. 6]: Administering the definition like Tar-water .
Parsing [sent. 228 len. 31]: While Mrs. Joe sat with her head bending over her needlework , I put my mouth into the forms of saying to Joe , `` What 's a convict ? ''
Parsing [sent. 229 len. 31]: Joe put his mouth into the forms of returning such a highly elaborate answer , that I could make out nothing of it but the single word `` Pip . ''
Parsing [sent. 230 len. 19]: `` There was a conwict off last night , '' said Joe , aloud , `` after sunset-gun .
Parsing [sent. 231 len. 7]: And they fired warning of him .
Parsing [sent. 232 len. 12]: And now it appears they 're firing warning of another . ''
Parsing [sent. 233 len. 6]: `` Who 's firing ? ''
Parsing [sent. 234 len. 26]: said I. `` Drat that boy , '' interposed my sister , frowning at me over her work , `` what a questioner he is .
Parsing [sent. 235 len. 13]: Ask no questions , and you 'll be told no lies . ''
Parsing [sent. 236 len. 28]: It was not very polite to herself , I thought , to imply that I should be told lies by her even if I did ask questions .
Parsing [sent. 237 len. 10]: But she never was polite unless there was company .
Parsing [sent. 238 len. 39]: At this point Joe greatly augmented my curiosity by taking the utmost pains to open his mouth very wide , and to put it into the form of a word that looked to me like `` sulks . ''
Parsing [sent. 239 len. 23]: Therefore , I naturally pointed to Mrs. Joe , and put my mouth into the form of saying , `` her ? ''

Parsing [sent. 241 len. 9]: But I could make nothing of the word .

Parsing [sent. 243 len. 7]: `` Lord bless the boy ! ''
Parsing [sent. 244 len. 17]: exclaimed my sister , as if she did n't quite mean that but rather the contrary .

Parsing [sent. 246 len. 4]: `` Oh-h ! ''
Parsing [sent. 247 len. 7]: said I , looking at Joe .

Parsing [sent. 249 len. 21]: Joe gave a reproachful cough , as much as to say , `` Well , I told you so . ''

Parsing [sent. 251 len. 12]: said I. `` That 's the way with this boy ! ''
Parsing [sent. 252 len. 20]: exclaimed my sister , pointing me out with her needle and thread , and shaking her head at me .

Parsing [sent. 255 len. 12]: We always used that name for marshes , in our country .

Parsing [sent. 257 len. 13]: said I , in a general way , and with quiet desperation .
Parsing [sent. 258 len. 12]: It was too much for Mrs. Joe , who immediately rose .
Parsing [sent. 259 len. 29]: `` I tell you what , young fellow , '' said she , `` I did n't bring you up by hand to badger people 's lives out .
Parsing [sent. 260 len. 14]: It would be blame to me and not praise , if I had .
Parsing [sent. 261 len. 33]: People are put in the Hulks because they murder , and because they rob , and forge , and do all sorts of bad ; and they always begin by asking questions .
Parsing [sent. 262 len. 9]: Now , you get along to bed ! ''
Parsing [sent. 263 len. 64]: I was never allowed a candle to light me to bed , and , as I went up stairs in the dark , with my head tingling , -- from Mrs. Joe 's thimble having played the tambourine upon it , to accompany her last words , -- I felt fearfully sensible of the great convenience that the hulks were handy for me .
Parsing [sent. 264 len. 8]: I was clearly on my way there .
Parsing [sent. 265 len. 16]: I had begun by asking questions , and I was going to rob Mrs. Joe .
Parsing [sent. 266 len. 29]: Since that time , which is far enough away now , I have often thought that few people know what secrecy there is in the young under terror .
Parsing [sent. 267 len. 13]: No matter how unreasonable the terror , so that it be terror .
Parsing [sent. 268 len. 85]: I was in mortal terror of the young man who wanted my heart and liver ; I was in mortal terror of my interlocutor with the iron leg ; I was in mortal terror of myself , from whom an awful promise had been extracted ; I had no hope of deliverance through my all-powerful sister , who repulsed me at every turn ; I am afraid to think of what I might have done on requirement , in the secrecy of my terror .
Parsing [sent. 269 len. 63]: If I slept at all that night , it was only to imagine myself drifting down the river on a strong spring-tide , to the Hulks ; a ghostly pirate calling out to me through a speaking-trumpet , as I passed the gibbet-station , that I had better come ashore and be hanged there at once , and not put it off .
Parsing [sent. 270 len. 30]: I was afraid to sleep , even if I had been inclined , for I knew that at the first faint dawn of morning I must rob the pantry .
Parsing [sent. 271 len. 50]: There was no doing it in the night , for there was no getting a light by easy friction then ; to have got one I must have struck it out of flint and steel , and have made a noise like the very pirate himself rattling his chains .
Parsing [sent. 272 len. 46]: As soon as the great black velvet pall outside my little window was shot with gray , I got up and went down stairs ; every board upon the way , and every crack in every board calling after me , `` Stop thief ! ''
Parsing [sent. 273 len. 9]: and `` Get up , Mrs. Joe ! ''
Parsing [sent. 274 len. 47]: In the pantry , which was far more abundantly supplied than usual , owing to the season , I was very much alarmed by a hare hanging up by the heels , whom I rather thought I caught when my back was half turned , winking .
Parsing [sent. 275 len. 25]: I had no time for verification , no time for selection , no time for anything , for I had no time to spare .
Parsing [sent. 276 len. 93]: I stole some bread , some rind of cheese , about half a jar of mincemeat -LRB- which I tied up in my pocket-handkerchief with my last night 's slice -RRB- , some brandy from a stone bottle -LRB- which I decanted into a glass bottle I had secretly used for making that intoxicating fluid , Spanish-liquorice-water , up in my room : diluting the stone bottle from a jug in the kitchen cupboard -RRB- , a meat bone with very little on it , and a beautiful round compact pork pie .
Parsing [sent. 277 len. 73]: I was nearly going away without the pie , but I was tempted to mount upon a shelf , to look what it was that was put away so carefully in a covered earthen ware dish in a corner , and I found it was the pie , and I took it in the hope that it was not intended for early use , and would not be missed for some time .
Parsing [sent. 278 len. 30]: There was a door in the kitchen , communicating with the forge ; I unlocked and unbolted that door , and got a file from among Joe 's tools .
Parsing [sent. 279 len. 36]: Then I put the fastenings as I had found them , opened the door at which I had entered when I ran home last night , shut it , and ran for the misty marshes .
Parsing [sent. 280 len. 12]: Chapter III It was a rimy morning , and very damp .
Parsing [sent. 281 len. 33]: I had seen the damp lying on the outside of my little window , as if some goblin had been crying there all night , and using the window for a pocket-handkerchief .
Parsing [sent. 282 len. 35]: Now , I saw the damp lying on the bare hedges and spare grass , like a coarser sort of spiders ' webs ; hanging itself from twig to twig and blade to blade .
Parsing [sent. 283 len. 56]: On every rail and gate , wet lay clammy , and the marsh mist was so thick , that the wooden finger on the post directing people to our village -- a direction which they never accepted , for they never came there -- was invisible to me until I was quite close under it .
Parsing [sent. 284 len. 28]: Then , as I looked up at it , while it dripped , it seemed to my oppressed conscience like a phantom devoting me to the Hulks .
Parsing [sent. 285 len. 29]: The mist was heavier yet when I got out upon the marshes , so that instead of my running at everything , everything seemed to run at me .
Parsing [sent. 286 len. 9]: This was very disagreeable to a guilty mind .
Parsing [sent. 287 len. 35]: The gates and dikes and banks came bursting at me through the mist , as if they cried as plainly as could be , `` A boy with Somebody 's else 's pork pie !
Parsing [sent. 288 len. 4]: Stop him ! ''
Parsing [sent. 289 len. 29]: The cattle came upon me with like suddenness , staring out of their eyes , and steaming out of their nostrils , `` Halloa , young thief ! ''
Parsing [sent. 290 len. 65]: One black ox , with a white cravat on , -- who even had to my awakened conscience something of a clerical air , -- fixed me so obstinately with his eyes , and moved his blunt head round in such an accusatory manner as I moved round , that I blubbered out to him , `` I could n't help it , sir !
Parsing [sent. 291 len. 10]: It was n't for myself I took it ! ''
Parsing [sent. 292 len. 33]: Upon which he put down his head , blew a cloud of smoke out of his nose , and vanished with a kick-up of his hind-legs and a flourish of his tail .
Parsing [sent. 293 len. 50]: All this time , I was getting on towards the river ; but however fast I went , I could n't warm my feet , to which the damp cold seemed riveted , as the iron was riveted to the leg of the man I was running to meet .
Parsing [sent. 294 len. 54]: I knew my way to the Battery , pretty straight , for I had been down there on a Sunday with Joe , and Joe , sitting on an old gun , had told me that when I was ` prentice to him , regularly bound , we would have such Larks there !
Parsing [sent. 295 len. 48]: However , in the confusion of the mist , I found myself at last too far to the right , and consequently had to try back along the river-side , on the bank of loose stones above the mud and the stakes that staked the tide out .
Parsing [sent. 296 len. 45]: Making my way along here with all despatch , I had just crossed a ditch which I knew to be very near the Battery , and had just scrambled up the mound beyond the ditch , when I saw the man sitting before me .
Parsing [sent. 297 len. 22]: His back was towards me , and he had his arms folded , and was nodding forward , heavy with sleep .
Parsing [sent. 298 len. 33]: I thought he would be more glad if I came upon him with his breakfast , in that unexpected manner , so I went forward softly and touched him on the shoulder .
Parsing [sent. 299 len. 17]: He instantly jumped up , and it was not the same man , but another man !
Parsing [sent. 300 len. 59]: And yet this man was dressed in coarse gray , too , and had a great iron on his leg , and was lame , and hoarse , and cold , and was everything that the other man was ; except that he had not the same face , and had a flat broad-brimmed low-crowned felt that on .
Parsing [sent. 301 len. 74]: All this I saw in a moment , for I had only a moment to see it in : he swore an oath at me , made a hit at me , -- it was a round weak blow that missed me and almost knocked himself down , for it made him stumble , -- and then he ran into the mist , stumbling twice as he went , and I lost him .
Parsing [sent. 302 len. 8]: `` It 's the young man ! ''
Parsing [sent. 303 len. 12]: I thought , feeling my heart shoot as I identified him .
Parsing [sent. 304 len. 23]: I dare say I should have felt a pain in my liver , too , if I had known where it was .

Parsing [sent. 398 len. 19]: Chapter IV I fully expected to find a Constable in the kitchen , waiting to take me up .

Parsing [sent. 411 len. 73]: Joe , who had ventured into the kitchen after me as the dustpan had retired before us , drew the back of his hand across his nose with a conciliatory air , when Mrs. Joe darted a look at him , and , when her eyes were withdrawn , secretly crossed his two forefingers , and exhibited them to me , as our token that Mrs. Joe was in a cross temper .
Parsing [sent. 412 len. 34]: This was so much her normal state , that Joe and I would often , for weeks together , be , as to our fingers , like monumental Crusaders as to their legs .
Parsing [sent. 413 len. 26]: We were to have a superb dinner , consisting of a leg of pickled pork and greens , and a pair of roast stuffed fowls .

Parsing [sent. 415 len. 58]: These extensive arrangements occasioned us to be cut off unceremoniously in respect of breakfast ; `` for I ai n't , '' said Mrs. Joe , -- `` I ai n't a going to have no formal cramming and busting and washing up now , with what I 've got before me , I promise you ! ''
Parsing [sent. 416 len. 49]: So , we had our slices served out , as if we were two thousand troops on a forced march instead of a man and boy at home ; and we took gulps of milk and water , with apologetic countenances , from a jug on the dresser .
Parsing [sent. 417 len. 98]: In the meantime , Mrs. Joe put clean white curtains up , and tacked a new flowered flounce across the wide chimney to replace the old one , and uncovered the little state parlor across the passage , which was never uncovered at any other time , but passed the rest of the year in a cool haze of silver paper , which even extended to the four little white crockery poodles on the mantel-shelf , each with a black nose and a basket of flowers in his mouth , and each the counterpart of the other .
Parsing [sent. 418 len. 25]: Mrs. Joe was a very clean housekeeper , but had an exquisite art of making her cleanliness more uncomfortable and unacceptable than dirt itself .
Parsing [sent. 419 len. 16]: Cleanliness is next to Godliness , and some people do the same by their religion .
Parsing [sent. 420 len. 26]: My sister , having so much to do , was going to church vicariously , that is to say , Joe and I were going .
Parsing [sent. 421 len. 32]: In his working -- clothes , Joe was a well-knit characteristic-looking blacksmith ; in his holiday clothes , he was more like a scarecrow in good circumstances , than anything else .
Parsing [sent. 422 len. 23]: Nothing that he wore then fitted him or seemed to belong to him ; and everything that he wore then grazed him .
Parsing [sent. 423 len. 31]: On the present festive occasion he emerged from his room , when the blithe bells were going , the picture of misery , in a full suit of Sunday penitentials .
Parsing [sent. 424 len. 51]: As to me , I think my sister must have had some general idea that I was a young offender whom an Accoucheur Policeman had taken up -LRB- on my birthday -RRB- and delivered over to her , to be dealt with according to the outraged majesty of the law .
Parsing [sent. 425 len. 35]: I was always treated as if I had insisted on being born in opposition to the dictates of reason , religion , and morality , and against the dissuading arguments of my best friends .
Parsing [sent. 426 len. 41]: Even when I was taken to have a new suit of clothes , the tailor had orders to make them like a kind of Reformatory , and on no account to let me have the free use of my limbs .
Parsing [sent. 427 len. 19]: Joe and I going to church , therefore , must have been a moving spectacle for compassionate minds .
Parsing [sent. 428 len. 14]: Yet , what I suffered outside was nothing to what I underwent within .
Parsing [sent. 429 len. 41]: The terrors that had assailed me whenever Mrs. Joe had gone near the pantry , or out of the room , were only to be equalled by the remorse with which my mind dwelt on what my hands had done .
Parsing [sent. 430 len. 36]: Under the weight of my wicked secret , I pondered whether the Church would be powerful enough to shield me from the vengeance of the terrible young man , if I divulged to that establishment .
Parsing [sent. 431 len. 27]: I conceived the idea that the time when the banns were read and when the clergyman said , `` Ye are now to declare it ! ''
Parsing [sent. 432 len. 17]: would be the time for me to rise and propose a private conference in the vestry .
Parsing [sent. 433 len. 32]: I am far from being sure that I might not have astonished our small congregation by resorting to this extreme measure , but for its being Christmas Day and no Sunday .

Parsing [sent. 439 len. 79]: Mr. Wopsle , united to a Roman nose and a large shining bald forehead , had a deep voice which he was uncommonly proud of ; indeed it was understood among his acquaintance that if you could only give him his head , he would read the clergyman into fits ; he himself confessed that if the Church was `` thrown open , '' meaning to competition , he would not despair of making his mark in it .
Parsing [sent. 440 len. 20]: The Church not being `` thrown open , '' he was , as I have said , our clerk .

Parsing [sent. 442 len. 48]: I opened the door to the company , -- making believe that it was a habit of ours to open that door , -- and I opened it first to Mr. Wopsle , next to Mr. and Mrs. Hubble , and last of all to Uncle Pumblechook .
Parsing [sent. 443 len. 15]: N.B. I was not allowed to call him uncle , under the severest penalties .
Parsing [sent. 444 len. 97]: `` Mrs. Joe , '' said Uncle Pumblechook , a large hard-breathing middle-aged slow man , with a mouth like a fish , dull staring eyes , and sandy hair standing upright on his head , so that he looked as if he had just been all but choked , and had that moment come to , `` I have brought you as the compliments of the season -- I have brought you , Mum , a bottle of sherry wine -- and I have brought you , Mum , a bottle of port wine . Parsing [sent. 455 len. 24]: Among this good company I should have felt myself , even if I had n't robbed the pantry , in a false position .

Parsing [sent. 625 len. 15]: The sergeant tossed off his glass again and seemed quite ready for another glass .

Parsing [sent. 627 len. 5]: Even I got some .
Parsing [sent. 628 len. 33]: And he was so very free of the wine that he even called for the other bottle , and handed that about with the same liberality , when the first was gone .
Parsing [sent. 629 len. 35]: As I watched them while they all stood clustering about the forge , enjoying themselves so much , I thought what terrible good sauce for a dinner my fugitive friend on the marshes was .
Parsing [sent. 630 len. 21]: They had not enjoyed themselves a quarter so much , before the entertainment was brightened with the excitement he furnished .
Parsing [sent. 631 len. 106]: And now , when they were all in lively anticipation of `` the two villains '' being taken , and when the bellows seemed to roar for the fugitives , the fire to flare for them , the smoke to hurry away in pursuit of them , Joe to hammer and clink for them , and all the murky shadows on the wall to shake at them in menace as the blaze rose and sank , and the red-hot sparks dropped and died , the pale afternoon outside almost seemed in my pitying young fancy to have turned pale on their account , poor wretches .
Parsing [sent. 632 len. 16]: At last , Joe 's job was done , and the ringing and roaring stopped .
Parsing [sent. 633 len. 30]: As Joe got on his coat , he mustered courage to propose that some of us should go down with the soldiers and see what came of the hunt .

Parsing [sent. 635 len. 16]: Joe said he was agreeable , and would take me , if Mrs. Joe approved .
Parsing [sent. 636 len. 29]: We never should have got leave to go , I am sure , but for Mrs. Joe 's curiosity to know all about it and how it ended .
Parsing [sent. 637 len. 37]: As it was , she merely stipulated , `` If you bring the boy back with his head blown to bits by a musket , do n't look to me to put it together again . ''
Parsing [sent. 638 len. 46]: The sergeant took a polite leave of the ladies , and parted from Mr. Pumblechook as from a comrade ; though I doubt if he were quite as fully sensible of that gentleman 's merits under arid conditions , as when something moist was going .
Parsing [sent. 639 len. 9]: His men resumed their muskets and fell in .
Parsing [sent. 640 len. 28]: Mr. Wopsle , Joe , and I , received strict charge to keep in the rear , and to speak no word after we reached the marshes .
Parsing [sent. 641 len. 36]: When we were all out in the raw air and were steadily moving towards our business , I treasonably whispered to Joe , `` I hope , Joe , we sha n't find them . ''
Parsing [sent. 642 len. 22]: and Joe whispered to me , `` I 'd give a shilling if they had cut and run , Pip . ''
Parsing [sent. 643 len. 43]: We were joined by no stragglers from the village , for the weather was cold and threatening , the way dreary , the footing bad , darkness coming on , and the people had good fires in-doors and were keeping the day .
Parsing [sent. 644 len. 17]: A few faces hurried to glowing windows and looked after us , but none came out .
Parsing [sent. 645 len. 13]: We passed the finger-post , and held straight on to the churchyard .
Parsing [sent. 646 len. 35]: There we were stopped a few minutes by a signal from the sergeant 's hand , while two or three of his men dispersed themselves among the graves , and also examined the porch .
Parsing [sent. 647 len. 28]: They came in again without finding anything , and then we struck out on the open marshes , through the gate at the side of the churchyard .
Parsing [sent. 648 len. 21]: A bitter sleet came rattling against us here on the east wind , and Joe took me on his back .
Parsing [sent. 649 len. 62]: Now that we were out upon the dismal wilderness where they little thought I had been within eight or nine hours and had seen both men hiding , I considered for the first time , with great dread , if we should come upon them , would my particular convict suppose that it was I who had brought the soldiers there ?
Parsing [sent. 650 len. 30]: He had asked me if I was a deceiving imp , and he had said I should be a fierce young hound if I joined the hunt against him .
Parsing [sent. 651 len. 19]: Would he believe that I was both imp and hound in treacherous earnest , and had betrayed him ?
Parsing [sent. 652 len. 11]: It was of no use asking myself this question now .
Parsing [sent. 653 len. 43]: There I was , on Joe 's back , and there was Joe beneath me , charging at the ditches like a hunter , and stimulating Mr. Wopsle not to tumble on his Roman nose , and to keep up with us .
Parsing [sent. 654 len. 22]: The soldiers were in front of us , extending into a pretty wide line with an interval between man and man .
Parsing [sent. 655 len. 20]: We were taking the course I had begun with , and from which I had diverged in the mist .
Parsing [sent. 656 len. 16]: Either the mist was not out again yet , or the wind had dispelled it .
Parsing [sent. 657 len. 41]: Under the low red glare of sunset , the beacon , and the gibbet , and the mound of the Battery , and the opposite shore of the river , were plain , though all of a watery lead color .
Parsing [sent. 658 len. 24]: With my heart thumping like a blacksmith at Joe 's broad shoulder , I looked all about for any sign of the convicts .
Parsing [sent. 659 len. 10]: I could see none , I could hear none .
Parsing [sent. 660 len. 36]: Mr. Wopsle had greatly alarmed me more than once , by his blowing and hard breathing ; but I knew the sounds by this time , and could dissociate them from the object of pursuit .
Parsing [sent. 661 len. 23]: I got a dreadful start , when I thought I heard the file still going ; but it was only a sheep-bell .
Parsing [sent. 662 len. 68]: The sheep stopped in their eating and looked timidly at us ; and the cattle , their heads turned from the wind and sleet , stared angrily as if they held us responsible for both annoyances ; but , except these things , and the shudder of the dying day in every blade of grass , there was no break in the bleak stillness of the marshes .
Parsing [sent. 663 len. 35]: The soldiers were moving on in the direction of the old Battery , and we were moving on a little way behind them , when , all of a sudden , we all stopped .
Parsing [sent. 664 len. 18]: For there had reached us on the wings of the wind and rain , a long shout .
Parsing [sent. 665 len. 4]: It was repeated .
Parsing [sent. 666 len. 16]: It was at a distance towards the east , but it was long and loud .
Parsing [sent. 667 len. 25]: Nay , there seemed to be two or more shouts raised together , -- if one might judge from a confusion in the sound .
Parsing [sent. 668 len. 22]: To this effect the sergeant and the nearest men were speaking under their breath , when Joe and I came up .
Parsing [sent. 669 len. 28]: After another moment 's listening , Joe -LRB- who was a good judge -RRB- agreed , and Mr. Wopsle -LRB- who was a bad judge -RRB- agreed .
Parsing [sent. 670 len. 38]: The sergeant , a decisive man , ordered that the sound should not be answered , but that the course should be changed , and that his men should make towards it `` at the double . ''
Parsing [sent. 671 len. 32]: So we slanted to the right -LRB- where the East was -RRB- , and Joe pounded away so wonderfully , that I had to hold on tight to keep my seat .
Parsing [sent. 672 len. 28]: It was a run indeed now , and what Joe called , in the only two words he spoke all the time , `` a Winder . ''
Parsing [sent. 673 len. 28]: Down banks and up banks , and over gates , and splashing into dikes , and breaking among coarse rushes : no man cared where he went .
Parsing [sent. 674 len. 24]: As we came nearer to the shouting , it became more and more apparent that it was made by more than one voice .
Parsing [sent. 675 len. 14]: Sometimes , it seemed to stop altogether , and then the soldiers stopped .
Parsing [sent. 676 len. 23]: When it broke out again , the soldiers made for it at a greater rate than ever , and we after them .
Parsing [sent. 677 len. 22]: After a while , we had so run it down , that we could hear one voice calling `` Murder ! ''

Parsing [sent. 679 len. 2]: Runaways !
Parsing [sent. 680 len. 2]: Guard !
Parsing [sent. 681 len. 8]: This way for the runaway convicts ! ''
Parsing [sent. 682 len. 19]: Then both voices would seem to be stifled in a struggle , and then would break out again .
Parsing [sent. 683 len. 18]: And when it had come to this , the soldiers ran like deer , and Joe too .

Parsing [sent. 685 len. 12]: Their pieces were cocked and levelled when we all ran in .

Parsing [sent. 773 len. 30]: We could not go fast , because of their lameness ; and they were so spent , that two or three times we had to halt while they rested .

Parsing [sent. 777 len. 35]: Three or four soldiers who lay upon it in their great-coats were not much interested in us , but just lifted their heads and took a sleepy stare , and then lay down again .

Parsing [sent. 810 len. 24]: Cribbed and barred and moored by massive rusty chains , the prison-ship seemed in my young eyes to be ironed like the prisoners .

Parsing [sent. 812 len. 27]: Then , the ends of the torches were flung hissing into the water , and went out , as if it were all over with him .
Parsing [sent. 813 len. 40]: Chapter VI My state of mind regarding the pilfering from which I had been so unexpectedly exonerated did not impel me to frank disclosure ; but I hope it had some dregs of good at the bottom of it .
Parsing [sent. 814 len. 29]: I do not recall that I felt any tenderness of conscience in reference to Mrs. Joe , when the fear of being found out was lifted off me .
Parsing [sent. 815 len. 41]: But I loved Joe , -- perhaps for no better reason in those early days than because the dear fellow let me love him , -- and , as to him , my inner self was not so easily composed .
Parsing [sent. 816 len. 29]: It was much upon my mind -LRB- particularly when I first saw him looking about for his file -RRB- that I ought to tell Joe the whole truth .
Parsing [sent. 817 len. 26]: Yet I did not , and for the reason that I mistrusted that if I did , he would think me worse than I was .
Parsing [sent. 818 len. 33]: The fear of losing Joe 's confidence , and of thenceforth sitting in the chimney corner at night staring drearily at my forever lost companion and friend , tied up my tongue .
Parsing [sent. 819 len. 34]: I morbidly represented to myself that if Joe knew it , I never afterwards could see him at the fireside feeling his fair whisker , without thinking that he was meditating on it .
Parsing [sent. 820 len. 46]: That , if Joe knew it , I never afterwards could see him glance , however casually , at yesterday 's meat or pudding when it came on to-day 's table , without thinking that he was debating whether I had been in the pantry .
Parsing [sent. 821 len. 45]: That , if Joe knew it , and at any subsequent period of our joint domestic life remarked that his beer was flat or thick , the conviction that he suspected Tar in it , would bring a rush of blood to my face .
Parsing [sent. 822 len. 33]: In a word , I was too cowardly to do what I knew to be right , as I had been too cowardly to avoid doing what I knew to be wrong .
Parsing [sent. 823 len. 26]: I had had no intercourse with the world at that time , and I imitated none of its many inhabitants who act in this manner .
Parsing [sent. 824 len. 17]: Quite an untaught genius , I made the discovery of the line of action for myself .
Parsing [sent. 825 len. 25]: As I was sleepy before we were far away from the prison-ship , Joe took me on his back again and carried me home .
Parsing [sent. 826 len. 49]: He must have had a tiresome journey of it , for Mr. Wopsle , being knocked up , was in such a very bad temper that if the Church had been thrown open , he would probably have excommunicated the whole expedition , beginning with Joe and myself .
Parsing [sent. 827 len. 53]: In his lay capacity , he persisted in sitting down in the damp to such an insane extent , that when his coat was taken off to be dried at the kitchen fire , the circumstantial evidence on his trousers would have hanged him , if it had been a capital offence .
Parsing [sent. 828 len. 45]: By that time , I was staggering on the kitchen floor like a little drunkard , through having been newly set upon my feet , and through having been fast asleep , and through waking in the heat and lights and noise of tongues .
Parsing [sent. 829 len. 24]: As I came to myself -LRB- with the aid of a heavy thump between the shoulders , and the restorative exclamation `` Yah !
Parsing [sent. 830 len. 10]: Was there ever such a boy as this ! ''
Parsing [sent. 831 len. 32]: from my sister , -RRB- I found Joe telling them about the convict 's confession , and all the visitors suggesting different ways by which he had got into the pantry .
Parsing [sent. 832 len. 79]: Mr. Pumblechook made out , after carefully surveying the premises , that he had first got upon the roof of the forge , and had then got upon the roof of the house , and had then let himself down the kitchen chimney by a rope made of his bedding cut into strips ; and as Mr. Pumblechook was very positive and drove his own chaise-cart -- over Everybody -- it was agreed that it must be so .
Parsing [sent. 833 len. 13]: Mr. Wopsle , indeed , wildly cried out , `` No ! ''
Parsing [sent. 834 len. 62]: with the feeble malice of a tired man ; but , as he had no theory , and no coat on , he was unanimously set at naught , -- not to mention his smoking hard behind , as he stood with his back to the kitchen fire to draw the damp out : which was not calculated to inspire confidence .
Parsing [sent. 835 len. 56]: This was all I heard that night before my sister clutched me , as a slumberous offence to the company 's eyesight , and assisted me up to bed with such a strong hand that I seemed to have fifty boots on , and to be dangling them all against the edges of the stairs .
Parsing [sent. 836 len. 41]: My state of mind , as I have described it , began before I was up in the morning , and lasted long after the subject had died out , and had ceased to be mentioned saving on exceptional occasions .
Parsing [sent. 837 len. 29]: Chapter VII At the time when I stood in the churchyard reading the family tombstones , I had just enough learning to be able to spell them out .
Parsing [sent. 838 len. 70]: My construction even of their simple meaning was not very correct , for I read `` wife of the Above '' as a complimentary reference to my father 's exaltation to a better world ; and if any one of my deceased relations had been referred to as `` Below , '' I have no doubt I should have formed the worst opinions of that member of the family .
Parsing [sent. 839 len. 85]: Neither were my notions of the theological positions to which my Catechism bound me , at all accurate ; for , I have a lively remembrance that I supposed my declaration that I was to `` walk in the same all the days of my life , '' laid me under an obligation always to go through the village from our house in one particular direction , and never to vary it by turning down by the wheelwright 's or up by the mill .
Parsing [sent. 840 len. 43]: When I was old enough , I was to be apprenticed to Joe , and until I could assume that dignity I was not to be what Mrs. Joe called `` Pompeyed , '' or -LRB- as I render it -RRB- pampered .
Parsing [sent. 841 len. 43]: Therefore , I was not only odd-boy about the forge , but if any neighbor happened to want an extra boy to frighten birds , or pick up stones , or do any such job , I was favored with the employment .
Parsing [sent. 842 len. 39]: In order , however , that our superior position might not be compromised thereby , a money-box was kept on the kitchen mantel-shelf , in to which it was publicly made known that all my earnings were dropped .
Parsing [sent. 843 len. 34]: I have an impression that they were to be contributed eventually towards the liquidation of the National Debt , but I know I had no hope of any personal participation in the treasure .
Parsing [sent. 844 len. 66]: Mr. Wopsle 's great-aunt kept an evening school in the village ; that is to say , she was a ridiculous old woman of limited means and unlimited infirmity , who used to go to sleep from six to seven every evening , in the society of youth who paid two pence per week each , for the improving opportunity of seeing her do it .
Parsing [sent. 845 len. 39]: She rented a small cottage , and Mr. Wopsle had the room up stairs , where we students used to overhear him reading aloud in a most dignified and terrific manner , and occasionally bumping on the ceiling .
Parsing [sent. 846 len. 16]: There was a fiction that Mr. Wopsle `` examined '' the scholars once a quarter .
Parsing [sent. 847 len. 31]: What he did on those occasions was to turn up his cuffs , stick up his hair , and give us Mark Antony 's oration over the body of Caesar .
Parsing [sent. 848 len. 38]: This was always followed by Collins 's Ode on the Passions , wherein I particularly venerated Mr. Wopsle as Revenge throwing his blood-stained sword in thunder down , and taking the War-denouncing trumpet with a withering look .
Parsing [sent. 849 len. 40]: It was not with me then , as it was in later life , when I fell into the society of the Passions , and compared them with Collins and Wopsle , rather to the disadvantage of both gentlemen .
Parsing [sent. 850 len. 22]: Mr. Wopsle 's great-aunt , besides keeping this Educational Institution , kept in the same room -- a little general shop .
Parsing [sent. 851 len. 50]: She had no idea what stock she had , or what the price of anything in it was ; but there was a little greasy memorandum-book kept in a drawer , which served as a Catalogue of Prices , and by this oracle Biddy arranged all the shop transaction .
Parsing [sent. 852 len. 30]: Biddy was Mr. Wopsle 's great-aunt 's granddaughter ; I confess myself quiet unequal to the working out of the problem , what relation she was to Mr. Wopsle .
Parsing [sent. 853 len. 19]: She was an orphan like myself ; like me , too , had been brought up by hand .

Parsing [sent. 1265 len. 43]: I was so humiliated , hurt , spurned , offended , angry , sorry , -- I can not hit upon the right name for the smart -- God knows what its name was , -- that tears started to my eyes .
Parsing [sent. 1266 len. 23]: The moment they sprang there , the girl looked at me with a quick delight in having been the cause of them .
Parsing [sent. 1267 len. 45]: This gave me power to keep them back and to look at her : so , she gave a contemptuous toss -- but with a sense , I thought , of having made too sure that I was so wounded -- and left me .
Parsing [sent. 1268 len. 48]: But when she was gone , I looked about me for a place to hide my face in , and got behind one of the gates in the brewery-lane , and leaned my sleeve against the wall there , and leaned my forehead on it and cried .
Parsing [sent. 1269 len. 38]: As I cried , I kicked the wall , and took a hard twist at my hair ; so bitter were my feelings , and so sharp was the smart without a name , that needed counteraction .
Parsing [sent. 1270 len. 10]: My sister 's bringing up had made me sensitive .
Parsing [sent. 1271 len. 28]: In the little world in which children have their existence whosoever brings them up , there is nothing so finely perceived and so finely felt as injustice .
Parsing [sent. 1272 len. 45]: It may be only small injustice that the child can be exposed to ; but the child is small , and its world is small , and its rocking-horse stands as many hands high , according to scale , as a big-boned Irish hunter .
Parsing [sent. 1273 len. 17]: Within myself , I had sustained , from my babyhood , a perpetual conflict with injustice .
Parsing [sent. 1274 len. 28]: I had known , from the time when I could speak , that my sister , in her capricious and violent coercion , was unjust to me .
Parsing [sent. 1275 len. 24]: I had cherished a profound conviction that her bringing me up by hand gave her no right to bring me up by jerks .
Parsing [sent. 1276 len. 55]: Through all my punishments , disgraces , fasts , and vigils , and other penitential performances , I had nursed this assurance ; and to my communing so much with it , in a solitary and unprotected way , I in great part refer the fact that I was morally timid and very sensitive .
Parsing [sent. 1277 len. 43]: I got rid of my injured feelings for the time by kicking them into the brewery wall , and twisting them out of my hair , and then I smoothed my face with my sleeve , and came from behind the gate .
Parsing [sent. 1278 len. 26]: The bread and meat were acceptable , and the beer was warming and tingling , and I was soon in spirits to look about me .
Parsing [sent. 1279 len. 55]: To be sure , it was a deserted place , down to the pigeon-house in the brewery-yard , which had been blown crooked on its pole by some high wind , and would have made the pigeons think themselves at sea , if there had been any pigeons there to be rocked by it .
Parsing [sent. 1280 len. 40]: But there were no pigeons in the dove-cot , no horses in the stable , no pigs in the sty , no malt in the storehouse , no smells of grains and beer in the copper or the vat .
Parsing [sent. 1281 len. 18]: All the uses and scents of the brewery might have evaporated with its last reek of smoke .
Parsing [sent. 1282 len. 58]: In a by-yard , there was a wilderness of empty casks , which had a certain sour remembrance of better days lingering about them ; but it was too sour to be accepted as a sample of the beer that was gone , -- and in this respect I remember those recluses as being like most others .
Parsing [sent. 1283 len. 90]: Behind the furthest end of the brewery , was a rank garden with an old wall ; not so high but that I could struggle up and hold on long enough to look over it , and see that the rank garden was the garden of the house , and that it was overgrown with tangled weeds , but that there was a track upon the green and yellow paths , as if some one sometimes walked there , and that Estella was walking away from me even then .
Parsing [sent. 1284 len. 7]: But she seemed to be everywhere .
Parsing [sent. 1285 len. 34]: For when I yielded to the temptation presented by the casks , and began to walk on them , I saw her walking on them at the end of the yard of casks .
Parsing [sent. 1286 len. 33]: She had her back towards me , and held her pretty brown hair spread out in her two hands , and never looked round , and passed out of my view directly .
Parsing [sent. 1287 len. 34]: So , in the brewery itself , -- by which I mean the large paved lofty place in which they used to make the beer , and where the brewing utensils still were .
Parsing [sent. 1288 len. 58]: When I first went into it , and , rather oppressed by its gloom , stood near the door looking about me , I saw her pass among the extinguished fires , and ascend some light iron stairs , and go out by a gallery high overhead , as if she were going out into the sky .
Parsing [sent. 1289 len. 20]: It was in this place , and at this moment , that a strange thing happened to my fancy .
Parsing [sent. 1290 len. 18]: I thought it a strange thing then , and I thought it a stranger thing long afterwards .
Parsing [sent. 1291 len. 46]: I turned my eyes -- a little dimmed by looking up at the frosty light -- towards a great wooden beam in a low nook of the building near me on my right hand , and I saw a figure hanging there by the neck .
Parsing [sent. 1292 len. 63]: A figure all in yellow white , with but one shoe to the feet ; and it hung so , that I could see that the faded trimmings of the dress were like earthy paper , and that the face was Miss Havisham 's , with a movement going over the whole countenance as if she were trying to call to me .
Parsing [sent. 1293 len. 38]: In the terror of seeing the figure , and in the terror of being certain that it had not been there a moment before , I at first ran from it , and then ran towards it .
Parsing [sent. 1294 len. 14]: And my terror was greatest of all when I found no figure there .
Parsing [sent. 1295 len. 45]: Nothing less than the frosty light of the cheerful sky , the sight of people passing beyond the bars of the court-yard gate , and the reviving influence of the rest of the bread and meat and beer , would have brought me round .
Parsing [sent. 1296 len. 33]: Even with those aids , I might not have come to myself as soon as I did , but that I saw Estella approaching with the keys , to let me out .
Parsing [sent. 1297 len. 29]: She would have some fair reason for looking down upon me , I thought , if she saw me frightened ; and she would have no fair reason .
Parsing [sent. 1298 len. 38]: She gave me a triumphant glance in passing me , as if she rejoiced that my hands were so coarse and my boots were so thick , and she opened the gate , and stood holding it .
Parsing [sent. 1299 len. 18]: I was passing out without looking at her , when she touched me with a taunting hand .
Parsing [sent. 1300 len. 8]: `` Why do n't you cry ? ''
Parsing [sent. 1301 len. 9]: `` Because I do n't want to . ''
Parsing [sent. 1302 len. 8]: `` You do , '' said she .
Parsing [sent. 1303 len. 20]: `` You have been crying till you are half blind , and you are near crying again now . ''
Parsing [sent. 1304 len. 15]: She laughed contemptuously , pushed me out , and locked the gate upon me .
Parsing [sent. 1305 len. 19]: I went straight to Mr. Pumblechook 's , and was immensely relieved to find him not at home .
Parsing [sent. 1306 len. 103]: So , leaving word with the shopman on what day I was wanted at Miss Havisham 's again , I set off on the four-mile walk to our forge ; pondering , as I went along , on all I had seen , and deeply revolving that I was a common laboring-boy ; that my hands were coarse ; that my boots were thick ; that I had fallen into a despicable habit of calling knaves Jacks ; that I was much more ignorant than I had considered myself last night , and generally that I was in a low-lived bad way .
Parsing [sent. 1307 len. 27]: Chapter IX When I reached home , my sister was very curious to know all about Miss Havisham 's , and asked a number of questions .
Parsing [sent. 1308 len. 45]: And I soon found myself getting heavily bumped from behind in the nape of the neck and the small of the back , and having my face ignominiously shoved against the kitchen wall , because I did not answer those questions at sufficient length .
Parsing [sent. 1309 len. 61]: If a dread of not being understood be hidden in the breasts of other young people to anything like the extent to which it used to be hidden in mine , -- which I consider probable , as I have no particular reason to suspect myself of having been a monstrosity , -- it is the key to many reservations .
Parsing [sent. 1310 len. 23]: I felt convinced that if I described Miss Havisham 's as my eyes had seen it , I should not be understood .
Parsing [sent. 1311 len. 61]: Not only that , but I felt convinced that Miss Havisham too would not be understood ; and although she was perfectly incomprehensible to me , I entertained an impression that there would be something coarse and treacherous in my dragging her as she really was -LRB- to say nothing of Miss Estella -RRB- before the contemplation of Mrs. Joe .
Parsing [sent. 1312 len. 20]: Consequently , I said as little as I could , and had my face shoved against the kitchen wall .
Parsing [sent. 1313 len. 45]: The worst of it was that that bullying old Pumblechook , preyed upon by a devouring curiosity to be informed of all I had seen and heard , came gaping over in his chaise-cart at tea-time , to have the details divulged to him .
Parsing [sent. 1314 len. 38]: And the mere sight of the torment , with his fishy eyes and mouth open , his sandy hair inquisitively on end , and his waistcoat heaving with windy arithmetic , made me vicious in my reticence .
Parsing [sent. 1315 len. 25]: `` Well , boy , '' Uncle Pumblechook began , as soon as he was seated in the chair of honor by the fire .
Parsing [sent. 1316 len. 10]: `` How did you get on up town ? ''
Parsing [sent. 1317 len. 19]: I answered , `` Pretty well , sir , '' and my sister shook her fist at me .
Parsing [sent. 1318 len. 5]: `` Pretty well ? ''
Parsing [sent. 1319 len. 4]: Mr. Pumblechook repeated .
Parsing [sent. 1320 len. 7]: `` Pretty well is no answer .

Parsing [sent. 1323 len. 16]: Anyhow , with whitewash from the wall on my forehead , my obstinacy was adamantine .
Parsing [sent. 1324 len. 25]: I reflected for some time , and then answered as if I had discovered a new idea , `` I mean pretty well . ''
Parsing [sent. 1325 len. 39]: My sister with an exclamation of impatience was going to fly at me , -- I had no shadow of defence , for Joe was busy in the forge , -- when Mr. Pumblechook interposed with `` No !

Parsing [sent. 1329 len. 34]: I calculated the consequences of replying `` Four Hundred Pound , '' and finding them against me , went as near the answer as I could -- which was somewhere about eightpence off .
Parsing [sent. 1330 len. 44]: Mr. Pumblechook then put me through my pence-table from `` twelve pence make one shilling , '' up to `` forty pence make three and fourpence , '' and then triumphantly demanded , as if he had done for me , `` Now !

Parsing [sent. 1332 len. 19]: To which I replied , after a long interval of reflection , `` I do n't know . ''

Parsing [sent. 1492 len. 38]: Chapter X The felicitous idea occurred to me a morning or two later when I woke , that the best step I could take towards making myself uncommon was to get out of Biddy everything she knew .
Parsing [sent. 1493 len. 56]: In pursuance of this luminous conception I mentioned to Biddy when I went to Mr. Wopsle 's great-aunt 's at night , that I had a particular reason for wishing to get on in life , and that I should feel very much obliged to her if she would impart all her learning to me .
Parsing [sent. 1494 len. 27]: Biddy , who was the most obliging of girls , immediately said she would , and indeed began to carry out her promise within five minutes .
Parsing [sent. 1495 len. 19]: The Educational scheme or Course established by Mr. Wopsle 's great-aunt may be resolved into the following synopsis .
Parsing [sent. 1496 len. 33]: The pupils ate apples and put straws down one another 's backs , until Mr. Wopsle 's great-aunt collected her energies , and made an indiscriminate totter at them with a birch-rod .
Parsing [sent. 1497 len. 26]: After receiving the charge with every mark of derision , the pupils formed in line and buzzingly passed a ragged book from hand to hand .
Parsing [sent. 1498 len. 29]: The book had an alphabet in it , some figures and tables , and a little spelling , -- that is to say , it had had once .
Parsing [sent. 1499 len. 29]: As soon as this volume began to circulate , Mr. Wopsle 's great-aunt fell into a state of coma , arising either from sleep or a rheumatic paroxysm .
Parsing [sent. 1500 len. 30]: The pupils then entered among themselves upon a competitive examination on the subject of Boots , with the view of ascertaining who could tread the hardest upon whose toes .
Parsing [sent. 1501 len. 69]: This mental exercise lasted until Biddy made a rush at them and distributed three defaced Bibles -LRB- shaped as if they had been unskilfully cut off the chump end of something -RRB- , more illegibly printed at the best than any curiosities of literature I have since met with , speckled all over with ironmould , and having various specimens of the insect world smashed between their leaves .
Parsing [sent. 1502 len. 18]: This part of the Course was usually lightened by several single combats between Biddy and refractory students .
Parsing [sent. 1503 len. 68]: When the fights were over , Biddy gave out the number of a page , and then we all read aloud what we could , -- or what we could n't -- in a frightful chorus ; Biddy leading with a high , shrill , monotonous voice , and none of us having the least notion of , or reverence for , what we were reading about .
Parsing [sent. 1504 len. 30]: When this horrible din had lasted a certain time , it mechanically awoke Mr. Wopsle 's great-aunt , who staggered at a boy fortuitously , and pulled his ears .
Parsing [sent. 1505 len. 23]: This was understood to terminate the Course for the evening , and we emerged into the air with shrieks of intellectual victory .
Parsing [sent. 1506 len. 90]: It is fair to remark that there was no prohibition against any pupil 's entertaining himself with a slate or even with the ink -LRB- when there was any -RRB- , but that it was not easy to pursue that branch of study in the winter season , on account of the little general shop in which the classes were holden -- and which was also Mr. Wopsle 's great-aunt 's sitting-room and bedchamber -- being but faintly illuminated through the agency of one low-spirited dip-candle and no snuffers .
Parsing [sent. 1507 len. 100]: It appeared to me that it would take time to become uncommon , under these circumstances : nevertheless , I resolved to try it , and that very evening Biddy entered on our special agreement , by imparting some information from her little catalogue of Prices , under the head of moist sugar , and lending me , to copy at home , a large old English D which she had imitated from the heading of some newspaper , and which I supposed , until she told me what it was , to be a design for a buckle .
Parsing [sent. 1508 len. 22]: Of course there was a public-house in the village , and of course Joe liked sometimes to smoke his pipe there .
Parsing [sent. 1509 len. 35]: I had received strict orders from my sister to call for him at the Three Jolly Bargemen , that evening , on my way from school , and bring him home at my peril .
Parsing [sent. 1510 len. 13]: To the Three Jolly Bargemen , therefore , I directed my steps .
Parsing [sent. 1511 len. 37]: There was a bar at the Jolly Bargemen , with some alarmingly long chalk scores in it on the wall at the side of the door , which seemed to me to be never paid off .
Parsing [sent. 1512 len. 18]: They had been there ever since I could remember , and had grown more than I had .
Parsing [sent. 1513 len. 24]: But there was a quantity of chalk about our country , and perhaps the people neglected no opportunity of turning it to account .
Parsing [sent. 1514 len. 73]: It being Saturday night , I found the landlord looking rather grimly at these records ; but as my business was with Joe and not with him , I merely wished him good evening , and passed into the common room at the end of the passage , where there was a bright large kitchen fire , and where Joe was smoking his pipe in company with Mr. Wopsle and a stranger .
Parsing [sent. 1515 len. 15]: Joe greeted me as usual with `` Halloa , Pip , old chap ! ''
Parsing [sent. 1516 len. 17]: and the moment he said that , the stranger turned his head and looked at me .
Parsing [sent. 1517 len. 12]: He was a secret-looking man whom I had never seen before .
Parsing [sent. 1518 len. 31]: His head was all on one side , and one of his eyes was half shut up , as if he were taking aim at something with an invisible gun .
Parsing [sent. 1519 len. 34]: He had a pipe in his mouth , and he took it out , and , after slowly blowing all his smoke away and looking hard at me all the time , nodded .
Parsing [sent. 1520 len. 26]: So , I nodded , and then he nodded again , and made room on the settle beside him that I might sit down there .
Parsing [sent. 1521 len. 42]: But as I was used to sit beside Joe whenever I entered that place of resort , I said `` No , thank you , sir , '' and fell into the space Joe made for me on the opposite settle .
Parsing [sent. 1522 len. 46]: The strange man , after glancing at Joe , and seeing that his attention was otherwise engaged , nodded to me again when I had taken my seat , and then rubbed his leg -- in a very odd way , as it struck me .
Parsing [sent. 1523 len. 23]: `` You was saying , '' said the strange man , turning to Joe , `` that you was a blacksmith . ''
Parsing [sent. 1524 len. 3]: `` Yes .
Parsing [sent. 1525 len. 11]: I said it , you know , '' said Joe .

Parsing [sent. 1628 len. 24]: Chapter XI At the appointed time I returned to Miss Havisham 's , and my hesitating ring at the gate brought out Estella .

Parsing [sent. 1633 len. 47]: Here , the daylight reappeared , and I found myself in a small paved courtyard , the opposite side of which was formed by a detached dwelling-house , that looked as if it had once belonged to the manager or head clerk of the extinct brewery .
Parsing [sent. 1634 len. 12]: There was a clock in the outer wall of this house .

Parsing [sent. 1640 len. 12]: This was my homely thought , as I contemplated the box-tree .
Parsing [sent. 1641 len. 60]: There had been some light snow , overnight , and it lay nowhere else to my knowledge ; but , it had not quite melted from the cold shadow of this bit of garden , and the wind caught it up in little eddies and threw it at the window , as if it pelted me for coming there .
Parsing [sent. 1642 len. 22]: I divined that my coming had stopped conversation in the room , and that its other occupants were looking at me .

Parsing [sent. 1741 len. 22]: From that room , too , the daylight was completely excluded , and it had an airless smell that was oppressive .
Parsing [sent. 1742 len. 48]: A fire had been lately kindled in the damp old-fashioned grate , and it was more disposed to go out than to burn up , and the reluctant smoke which hung in the room seemed colder than the clearer air , -- like our own marsh mist .
Parsing [sent. 1743 len. 28]: Certain wintry branches of candles on the high chimney-piece faintly lighted the chamber ; or it would be more expressive to say , faintly troubled its darkness .
Parsing [sent. 1744 len. 31]: It was spacious , and I dare say had once been handsome , but every discernible thing in it was covered with dust and mould , and dropping to pieces .
Parsing [sent. 1745 len. 33]: The most prominent object was a long table with a tablecloth spread on it , as if a feast had been in preparation when the house and the clocks all stopped together .
Parsing [sent. 1746 len. 88]: An epergne or centre-piece of some kind was in the middle of this cloth ; it was so heavily overhung with cobwebs that its form was quite undistinguishable ; and , as I looked along the yellow expanse out of which I remember its seeming to grow , like a black fungus , I saw speckle-legged spiders with blotchy bodies running home to it , and running out from it , as if some circumstances of the greatest public importance had just transpired in the spider community .
Parsing [sent. 1747 len. 22]: I heard the mice too , rattling behind the panels , as if the same occurrence were important to their interests .
Parsing [sent. 1748 len. 40]: But the black beetles took no notice of the agitation , and groped about the hearth in a ponderous elderly way , as if they were short-sighted and hard of hearing , and not on terms with one another .
Parsing [sent. 1749 len. 27]: These crawling things had fascinated my attention , and I was watching them from a distance , when Miss Havisham laid a hand upon my shoulder .
Parsing [sent. 1750 len. 24]: In her other hand she had a crutch-headed stick on which she leaned , and she looked like the Witch of the place .
Parsing [sent. 1751 len. 28]: `` This , '' said she , pointing to the long table with her stick , `` is where I will be laid when I am dead .
Parsing [sent. 1752 len. 10]: They shall come and look at me here . ''
Parsing [sent. 1753 len. 36]: With some vague misgiving that she might get upon the table then and there and die at once , the complete realization of the ghastly waxwork at the Fair , I shrank under her touch .
Parsing [sent. 1754 len. 9]: `` What do you think that is ? ''
Parsing [sent. 1755 len. 19]: she asked me , again pointing with her stick ; `` that , where those cobwebs are ? ''
Parsing [sent. 1756 len. 12]: `` I ca n't guess what it is , ma'am . ''
Parsing [sent. 1757 len. 7]: `` It 's a great cake .
Parsing [sent. 1758 len. 3]: A bride-cake .
Parsing [sent. 1759 len. 3]: Mine ! ''
Parsing [sent. 1760 len. 32]: She looked all round the room in a glaring manner , and then said , leaning on me while her hand twitched my shoulder , `` Come , come , come !
Parsing [sent. 1761 len. 7]: Walk me , walk me ! ''
Parsing [sent. 1762 len. 25]: I made out from this , that the work I had to do , was to walk Miss Havisham round and round the room .
Parsing [sent. 1763 len. 43]: Accordingly , I started at once , and she leaned upon my shoulder , and we went away at a pace that might have been an imitation -LRB- founded on my first impulse under that roof -RRB- of Mr. Pumblechook 's chaise-cart .
Parsing [sent. 1764 len. 17]: She was not physically strong , and after a little time said , `` Slower ! ''
Parsing [sent. 1765 len. 44]: Still , we went at an impatient fitful speed , and as we went , she twitched the hand upon my shoulder , and worked her mouth , and led me to believe that we were going fast because her thoughts went fast .
Parsing [sent. 1766 len. 11]: After a while she said , `` Call Estella ! ''
Parsing [sent. 1767 len. 20]: so I went out on the landing and roared that name as I had done on the previous occasion .
Parsing [sent. 1768 len. 22]: When her light appeared , I returned to Miss Havisham , and we started away again round and round the room .
Parsing [sent. 1769 len. 46]: If only Estella had come to be a spectator of our proceedings , I should have felt sufficiently discontented ; but as she brought with her the three ladies and the gentleman whom I had seen below , I did n't know what to do .
Parsing [sent. 1770 len. 39]: In my politeness , I would have stopped ; but Miss Havisham twitched my shoulder , and we posted on , -- with a shame-faced consciousness on my part that they would think it was all my doing .
Parsing [sent. 1771 len. 11]: `` Dear Miss Havisham , '' said Miss Sarah Pocket .
Parsing [sent. 1772 len. 7]: `` How well you look ! ''
Parsing [sent. 1773 len. 10]: `` I do not , '' returned Miss Havisham .
Parsing [sent. 1774 len. 9]: `` I am yellow skin and bone . ''
Parsing [sent. 1775 len. 26]: Camilla brightened when Miss Pocket met with this rebuff ; and she murmured , as she plaintively contemplated Miss Havisham , `` Poor dear soul !
Parsing [sent. 1776 len. 12]: Certainly not to be expected to look well , poor thing .
Parsing [sent. 1777 len. 4]: The idea ! ''
Parsing [sent. 1778 len. 7]: `` And how are you ? ''
Parsing [sent. 1779 len. 6]: said Miss Havisham to Camilla .
Parsing [sent. 1780 len. 25]: As we were close to Camilla then , I would have stopped as a matter of course , only Miss Havisham would n't stop .
Parsing [sent. 1781 len. 15]: We swept on , and I felt that I was highly obnoxious to Camilla .
Parsing [sent. 1782 len. 22]: `` Thank you , Miss Havisham , '' she returned , `` I am as well as can be expected . ''
Parsing [sent. 1783 len. 11]: `` Why , what 's the matter with you ? ''
Parsing [sent. 1784 len. 8]: asked Miss Havisham , with exceeding sharpness .
Parsing [sent. 1785 len. 9]: `` Nothing worth mentioning , '' replied Camilla .
Parsing [sent. 1786 len. 32]: `` I do n't wish to make a display of my feelings , but I have habitually thought of you more in the night than I am quite equal to . ''
Parsing [sent. 1787 len. 13]: `` Then do n't think of me , '' retorted Miss Havisham .
Parsing [sent. 1788 len. 6]: `` Very easily said ! ''
Parsing [sent. 1789 len. 22]: remarked Camilla , amiably repressing a sob , while a hitch came into her upper lip , and her tears overflowed .
Parsing [sent. 1790 len. 19]: `` Raymond is a witness what ginger and sal volatile I am obliged to take in the night .
Parsing [sent. 1791 len. 13]: Raymond is a witness what nervous jerkings I have in my legs .
Parsing [sent. 1792 len. 22]: Chokings and nervous jerkings , however , are nothing new to me when I think with anxiety of those I love .
Parsing [sent. 1793 len. 22]: If I could be less affectionate and sensitive , I should have a better digestion and an iron set of nerves .
Parsing [sent. 1794 len. 10]: I am sure I wish it could be so .
Parsing [sent. 1795 len. 15]: But as to not thinking of you in the night -- The idea ! ''
Parsing [sent. 1796 len. 7]: Here , a burst of tears .
Parsing [sent. 1797 len. 22]: The Raymond referred to , I understood to be the gentleman present , and him I understood to be Mr. Camilla .
Parsing [sent. 1798 len. 51]: He came to the rescue at this point , and said in a consolatory and complimentary voice , `` Camilla , my dear , it is well known that your family feelings are gradually undermining you to the extent of making one of your legs shorter than the other . ''
Parsing [sent. 1799 len. 40]: `` I am not aware , '' observed the grave lady whose voice I had heard but once , `` that to think of any person is to make a great claim upon that person , my dear . ''
Parsing [sent. 1800 len. 58]: Miss Sarah Pocket , whom I now saw to be a little dry , brown , corrugated old woman , with a small face that might have been made of walnut-shells , and a large mouth like a cat 's without the whiskers , supported this position by saying , `` No , indeed , my dear .
Parsing [sent. 1801 len. 3]: Hem ! ''
Parsing [sent. 1802 len. 12]: `` Thinking is easy enough , '' said the grave lady .

Parsing [sent. 1804 len. 5]: assented Miss Sarah Pocket .

Parsing [sent. 1806 len. 16]: cried Camilla , whose fermenting feelings appeared to rise from her legs to her bosom .
Parsing [sent. 1807 len. 7]: `` It 's all very true !
Parsing [sent. 1808 len. 16]: It 's a weakness to be so affectionate , but I ca n't help it .
Parsing [sent. 1809 len. 24]: No doubt my health would be much better if it was otherwise , still I would n't change my disposition if I could .
Parsing [sent. 1810 len. 28]: It 's the cause of much suffering , but it 's a consolation to know I posses it , when I wake up in the night . ''
Parsing [sent. 1811 len. 6]: Here another burst of feeling .

Parsing [sent. 1814 len. 3]: said Camilla .

Parsing [sent. 1817 len. 30]: `` I have gone off into that state , hours and hours , on account of Matthew 's strange and inexplicable conduct , and nobody has thanked me . ''

Parsing [sent. 1821 len. 115]: `` Without expecting any thanks , or anything of the sort , '' resumed Camilla , `` I have remained in that state , hours and hours , and Raymond is a witness of the extent to which I have choked , and what the total inefficacy of ginger has been , and I have been heard at the piano-forte tuner 's across the street , where the poor mistaken children have even supposed it to be pigeons cooing at a distance , -- and now to be told -- '' Here Camilla put her hand to her throat , and began to be quite chemical as to the formation of new combinations there .
Parsing [sent. 1822 len. 21]: When this same Matthew was mentioned , Miss Havisham stopped me and herself , and stood looking at the speaker .
Parsing [sent. 1823 len. 16]: This change had a great influence in bringing Camilla 's chemistry to a sudden end .

Parsing [sent. 1850 len. 16]: They come here on the day , but they dare not refer to it . ''
Parsing [sent. 1851 len. 12]: Of course I made no further effort to refer to it .

Parsing [sent. 1854 len. 20]: The mice have gnawed at it , and sharper teeth than teeth of mice have gnawed at me . ''
Parsing [sent. 1855 len. 50]: She held the head of her stick against her heart as she stood looking at the table ; she in her once white dress , all yellow and withered ; the once white cloth all yellow and withered ; everything around in a state to crumble under a touch .

Parsing [sent. 1857 len. 18]: She stood looking at the table as if she stood looking at her own figure lying there .
Parsing [sent. 1858 len. 4]: I remained quiet .
Parsing [sent. 1859 len. 9]: Estella returned , and she too remained quiet .
Parsing [sent. 1860 len. 13]: It seemed to me that we continued thus for a long time .
Parsing [sent. 1861 len. 35]: In the heavy air of the room , and the heavy darkness that brooded in its remoter corners , I even had an alarming fancy that Estella and I might presently begin to decay .
Parsing [sent. 1862 len. 38]: At length , not coming out of her distraught state by degrees , but in an instant , Miss Havisham said , `` Let me see you two play cards ; why have you not begun ? ''
Parsing [sent. 1863 len. 62]: With that , we returned to her room , and sat down as before ; I was beggared , as before ; and again , as before , Miss Havisham watched us all the time , directed my attention to Estella 's beauty , and made me notice it the more by trying her jewels on Estella 's breast and hair .
Parsing [sent. 1864 len. 21]: Estella , for her part , likewise treated me as before , except that she did not condescend to speak .

Parsing [sent. 1866 len. 15]: There , too , I was again left to wander about as I liked .
Parsing [sent. 1867 len. 37]: It is not much to the purpose whether a gate in that garden wall which I had scrambled up to peep over on the last occasion was , on that last occasion , open or shut .
Parsing [sent. 1868 len. 15]: Enough that I saw no gate then , and that I saw one now .

Parsing [sent. 1870 len. 53]: It was quite a wilderness , and there were old melon-frames and cucumber-frames in it , which seemed in their decline to have produced a spontaneous growth of weak attempts at pieces of old hats and boots , with now and then a weedy offshoot into the likeness of a battered saucepan .
Parsing [sent. 1871 len. 38]: When I had exhausted the garden and a greenhouse with nothing in it but a fallen-down grape-vine and some bottles , I found myself in the dismal corner upon which I had looked out of the window .
Parsing [sent. 1872 len. 44]: Never questioning for a moment that the house was now empty , I looked in at another window , and found myself , to my great surprise , exchanging a broad stare with a pale young gentleman with red eyelids and light hair .
Parsing [sent. 1873 len. 12]: This pale young gentleman quickly disappeared , and reappeared beside me .
Parsing [sent. 1874 len. 24]: He had been at his books when I had found myself staring at him , and I now saw that he was inky .

Parsing [sent. 1876 len. 8]: said he , `` young fellow ! ''
Parsing [sent. 1877 len. 24]: Halloa being a general observation which I had usually observed to be best answered by itself , I said , `` Halloa ! ''

Parsing [sent. 1883 len. 5]: `` Miss Estella . ''
Parsing [sent. 1884 len. 12]: `` Come and fight , '' said the pale young gentleman .
Parsing [sent. 1885 len. 8]: What could I do but follow him ?
Parsing [sent. 1886 len. 16]: I have often asked myself the question since ; but what else could I do ?
Parsing [sent. 1887 len. 28]: His manner was so final , and I was so astonished , that I followed where he led , as if I had been under a spell .

Parsing [sent. 1890 len. 5]: There it is ! ''
Parsing [sent. 1891 len. 44]: In a most irritating manner he instantly slapped his hands against one another , daintily flung one of his legs up behind him , pulled my hair , slapped his hands again , dipped his head , and butted it into my stomach .
Parsing [sent. 1892 len. 30]: The bull-like proceeding last mentioned , besides that it was unquestionably to be regarded in the light of a liberty , was particularly disagreeable just after bread and meat .
Parsing [sent. 1893 len. 21]: I therefore hit out at him and was going to hit out again , when he said , `` Aha !

Parsing [sent. 1895 len. 16]: and began dancing backwards and forwards in a manner quite unparalleled within my limited experience .
Parsing [sent. 1896 len. 7]: `` Laws of the game ! ''
Parsing [sent. 1897 len. 3]: said he .
Parsing [sent. 1898 len. 13]: Here , he skipped from his left leg on to his right .
Parsing [sent. 1899 len. 5]: `` Regular rules ! ''
Parsing [sent. 1900 len. 13]: Here , he skipped from his right leg on to his left .
Parsing [sent. 1901 len. 13]: `` Come to the ground , and go through the preliminaries ! ''
Parsing [sent. 1902 len. 21]: Here , he dodged backwards and forwards , and did all sorts of things while I looked helplessly at him .
Parsing [sent. 1903 len. 55]: I was secretly afraid of him when I saw him so dexterous ; but I felt morally and physically convinced that his light head of hair could have had no business in the pit of my stomach , and that I had a right to consider it irrelevant when so obtruded on my attention .
Parsing [sent. 1904 len. 30]: Therefore , I followed him without a word , to a retired nook of the garden , formed by the junction of two walls and screened by some rubbish .
Parsing [sent. 1905 len. 44]: On his asking me if I was satisfied with the ground , and on my replying Yes , he begged my leave to absent himself for a moment , and quickly returned with a bottle of water and a sponge dipped in vinegar .
Parsing [sent. 1906 len. 15]: `` Available for both , '' he said , placing these against the wall .
Parsing [sent. 1907 len. 31]: And then fell to pulling off , not only his jacket and waistcoat , but his shirt too , in a manner at once light-hearted , business-like , and bloodthirsty .
Parsing [sent. 1908 len. 31]: Although he did not look very healthy , -- having pimples on his face , and a breaking out at his mouth , -- these dreadful preparations quite appalled me .
Parsing [sent. 1909 len. 31]: I judged him to be about my own age , but he was much taller , and he had a way of spinning himself about that was full of appearance .
Parsing [sent. 1910 len. 43]: For the rest , he was a young gentleman in a gray suit -LRB- when not denuded for battle -RRB- , with his elbows , knees , wrists , and heels considerably in advance of the rest of him as to development .
Parsing [sent. 1911 len. 31]: My heart failed me when I saw him squaring at me with every demonstration of mechanical nicety , and eyeing my anatomy as if he were minutely choosing his bone .
Parsing [sent. 1912 len. 43]: I never have been so surprised in my life , as I was when I let out the first blow , and saw him lying on his back , looking up at me with a bloody nose and his face exceedingly fore-shortened .
Parsing [sent. 1913 len. 23]: But , he was on his feet directly , and after sponging himself with a great show of dexterity began squaring again .
Parsing [sent. 1914 len. 29]: The second greatest surprise I have ever had in my life was seeing him on his back again , looking up at me out of a black eye .
Parsing [sent. 1915 len. 8]: His spirit inspired me with great respect .
Parsing [sent. 1916 len. 78]: He seemed to have no strength , and he never once hit me hard , and he was always knocked down ; but he would be up again in a moment , sponging himself or drinking out of the water-bottle , with the greatest satisfaction in seconding himself according to form , and then came at me with an air and a show that made me believe he really was going to do for me at last .
Parsing [sent. 1917 len. 52]: He got heavily bruised , for I am sorry to record that the more I hit him , the harder I hit him ; but he came up again and again and again , until at last he got a bad fall with the back of his head against the wall .
Parsing [sent. 1918 len. 56]: Even after that crisis in our affairs , he got up and turned round and round confusedly a few times , not knowing where I was ; but finally went on his knees to his sponge and threw it up : at the same time panting out , `` That means you have won . ''
Parsing [sent. 1919 len. 26]: He seemed so brave and innocent , that although I had not proposed the contest , I felt but a gloomy satisfaction in my victory .
Parsing [sent. 1920 len. 27]: Indeed , I go so far as to hope that I regarded myself while dressing as a species of savage young wolf or other wild beast .
Parsing [sent. 1921 len. 25]: However , I got dressed , darkly wiping my sanguinary face at intervals , and I said , `` Can I help you ? ''
Parsing [sent. 1922 len. 25]: and he said `` No thankee , '' and I said `` Good afternoon , '' and he said `` Same to you . ''
Parsing [sent. 1923 len. 15]: When I got into the courtyard , I found Estella waiting with the keys .
Parsing [sent. 1924 len. 37]: But she neither asked me where I had been , nor why I had kept her waiting ; and there was a bright flush upon her face , as though something had happened to delight her .
Parsing [sent. 1925 len. 21]: Instead of going straight to the gate , too , she stepped back into the passage , and beckoned me .
