Parsing [sent. 6031 len. 9]: `` And must obey , '' said I .
Parsing [sent. 6032 len. 35]: This was all the preparation I received for that visit , or for others like it ; Miss Havisham never wrote to me , nor had I ever so much as seen her handwriting .
Parsing [sent. 6033 len. 39]: We went down on the next day but one , and we found her in the room where I had first beheld her , and it is needless to add that there was no change in Satis House .
Parsing [sent. 6034 len. 40]: She was even more dreadfully fond of Estella than she had been when I last saw them together ; I repeat the word advisedly , for there was something positively dreadful in the energy of her looks and embraces .
Parsing [sent. 6035 len. 42]: She hung upon Estella 's beauty , hung upon her words , hung upon her gestures , and sat mumbling her own trembling fingers while she looked at her , as though she were devouring the beautiful creature she had reared .
Parsing [sent. 6036 len. 23]: From Estella she looked at me , with a searching glance that seemed to pry into my heart and probe its wounds .
Parsing [sent. 6037 len. 16]: `` How does she use you , Pip ; how does she use you ? ''
Parsing [sent. 6038 len. 16]: she asked me again , with her witch-like eagerness , even in Estella 's hearing .
Parsing [sent. 6039 len. 118]: But , when we sat by her flickering fire at night , she was most weird ; for then , keeping Estella 's hand drawn through her arm and clutched in her own hand , she extorted from her , by dint of referring back to what Estella had told her in her regular letters , the names and conditions of the men whom she had fascinated ; and as Miss Havisham dwelt upon this roll , with the intensity of a mind mortally hurt and diseased , she sat with her other hand on her crutch stick , and her chin on that , and her wan bright eyes glaring at me , a very spectre .
Parsing [sent. 6040 len. 62]: I saw in this , wretched though it made me , and bitter the sense of dependence and even of degradation that it awakened , -- I saw in this that Estella was set to wreak Miss Havisham 's revenge on men , and that she was not to be given to me until she had gratified it for a term .
Parsing [sent. 6041 len. 15]: I saw in this , a reason for her being beforehand assigned to me .
Parsing [sent. 6042 len. 42]: Sending her out to attract and torment and do mischief , Miss Havisham sent her with the malicious assurance that she was beyond the reach of all admirers , and that all who staked upon that cast were secured to lose .
Parsing [sent. 6043 len. 26]: I saw in this that I , too , was tormented by a perversion of ingenuity , even while the prize was reserved for me .
Parsing [sent. 6044 len. 34]: I saw in this the reason for my being staved off so long and the reason for my late guardian 's declining to commit himself to the formal knowledge of such a scheme .
Parsing [sent. 6045 len. 55]: In a word , I saw in this Miss Havisham as I had her then and there before my eyes , and always had had her before my eyes ; and I saw in this , the distinct shadow of the darkened and unhealthy house in which her life was hidden from the sun .
Parsing [sent. 6046 len. 16]: The candles that lighted that room of hers were placed in sconces on the wall .
Parsing [sent. 6047 len. 24]: They were high from the ground , and they burnt with the steady dulness of artificial light in air that is seldom renewed .
Parsing [sent. 6048 len. 78]: As I looked round at them , and at the pale gloom they made , and at the stopped clock , and at the withered articles of bridal dress upon the table and the ground , and at her own awful figure with its ghostly reflection thrown large by the fire upon the ceiling and the wall , I saw in everything the construction that my mind had come to , repeated and thrown back to me .
Parsing [sent. 6049 len. 76]: My thoughts passed into the great room across the landing where the table was spread , and I saw it written , as it were , in the falls of the cobwebs from the centre-piece , in the crawlings of the spiders on the cloth , in the tracks of the mice as they betook their little quickened hearts behind the panels , and in the gropings and pausings of the beetles on the floor .
Parsing [sent. 6050 len. 19]: It happened on the occasion of this visit that some sharp words arose between Estella and Miss Havisham .
Parsing [sent. 6051 len. 12]: It was the first time I had ever seen them opposed .
Parsing [sent. 6052 len. 42]: We were seated by the fire , as just now described , and Miss Havisham still had Estella 's arm drawn through her own , and still clutched Estella 's hand in hers , when Estella gradually began to detach herself .
Parsing [sent. 6053 len. 24]: She had shown a proud impatience more than once before , and had rather endured that fierce affection than accepted or returned it .
Parsing [sent. 6054 len. 4]: `` What ! ''
Parsing [sent. 6055 len. 18]: said Miss Havisham , flashing her eyes upon her , `` are you tired of me ? ''
Parsing [sent. 6056 len. 32]: `` Only a little tired of myself , '' replied Estella , disengaging her arm , and moving to the great chimney-piece , where she stood looking down at the fire .
Parsing [sent. 6057 len. 9]: `` Speak the truth , you ingrate ! ''
Parsing [sent. 6058 len. 20]: cried Miss Havisham , passionately striking her stick upon the floor ; `` you are tired of me . ''
Parsing [sent. 6059 len. 16]: Estella looked at her with perfect composure , and again looked down at the fire .
Parsing [sent. 6060 len. 24]: Her graceful figure and her beautiful face expressed a self-possessed indifference to the wild heat of the other , that was almost cruel .
Parsing [sent. 6061 len. 7]: `` You stock and stone ! ''
Parsing [sent. 6062 len. 4]: exclaimed Miss Havisham .
Parsing [sent. 6063 len. 8]: `` You cold , cold heart ! ''
Parsing [sent. 6064 len. 4]: `` What ? ''
Parsing [sent. 6065 len. 30]: said Estella , preserving her attitude of indifference as she leaned against the great chimney-piece and only moving her eyes ; `` do you reproach me for being cold ?
Parsing [sent. 6066 len. 3]: You ? ''
Parsing [sent. 6067 len. 6]: `` Are you not ? ''
Parsing [sent. 6068 len. 5]: was the fierce retort .
Parsing [sent. 6069 len. 9]: `` You should know , '' said Estella .
Parsing [sent. 6070 len. 9]: `` I am what you have made me .
Parsing [sent. 6071 len. 27]: Take all the praise , take all the blame ; take all the success , take all the failure ; in short , take me . ''
Parsing [sent. 6072 len. 12]: `` O , look at her , look at her ! ''
Parsing [sent. 6073 len. 23]: cried Miss Havisham , bitterly ; `` Look at her so hard and thankless , on the hearth where she was reared !
Parsing [sent. 6074 len. 29]: Where I took her into this wretched breast when it was first bleeding from its stabs , and where I have lavished years of tenderness upon her ! ''
Parsing [sent. 6075 len. 38]: `` At least I was no party to the compact , '' said Estella , `` for if I could walk and speak , when it was made , it was as much as I could do .
Parsing [sent. 6076 len. 6]: But what would you have ?
Parsing [sent. 6077 len. 15]: You have been very good to me , and I owe everything to you .
Parsing [sent. 6078 len. 6]: What would you have ? ''
Parsing [sent. 6079 len. 8]: `` Love , '' replied the other .
Parsing [sent. 6080 len. 6]: `` You have it . ''
Parsing [sent. 6081 len. 10]: `` I have not , '' said Miss Havisham .
Parsing [sent. 6082 len. 52]: `` Mother by adoption , '' retorted Estella , never departing from the easy grace of her attitude , never raising her voice as the other did , never yielding either to anger or tenderness , -- `` mother by adoption , I have said that I owe everything to you .
Parsing [sent. 6083 len. 7]: All I possess is freely yours .
Parsing [sent. 6084 len. 15]: All that you have given me , is at your command to have again .
Parsing [sent. 6085 len. 7]: Beyond that , I have nothing .
Parsing [sent. 6086 len. 25]: And if you ask me to give you , what you never gave me , my gratitude and duty can not do impossibilities . ''
Parsing [sent. 6087 len. 9]: `` Did I never give her love ! ''
Parsing [sent. 6088 len. 9]: cried Miss Havisham , turning wildly to me .
Parsing [sent. 6089 len. 29]: `` Did I never give her a burning love , inseparable from jealousy at all times , and from sharp pain , while she speaks thus to me !
Parsing [sent. 6090 len. 13]: Let her call me mad , let her call me mad ! ''
Parsing [sent. 6091 len. 19]: `` Why should I call you mad , '' returned Estella , `` I , of all people ?

Parsing [sent. 6093 len. 21]: Does any one live , who knows what a steady memory you have , half as well as I do ?
Parsing [sent. 6094 len. 40]: I who have sat on this same hearth on the little stool that is even now beside you there , learning your lessons and looking up into your face , when your face was strange and frightened me ! ''

Parsing [sent. 6112 len. 11]: `` Who praised me when I learnt my lesson ? ''

Parsing [sent. 6120 len. 14]: I have never shown any weakness that I can charge myself with . ''

Parsing [sent. 6125 len. 77]: If you had brought up your adopted daughter wholly in the dark confinement of these rooms , and had never let her know that there was such a thing as the daylight by which she had never once seen your face , -- if you had done that , and then , for a purpose had wanted her to understand the daylight and know all about it , you would have been disappointed and angry ? ''
Parsing [sent. 6126 len. 28]: Miss Havisham , with her head in her hands , sat making a low moaning , and swaying herself on her chair , but gave no answer .
Parsing [sent. 6127 len. 115]: `` Or , '' said Estella , -- `` which is a nearer case , -- if you had taught her , from the dawn of her intelligence , with your utmost energy and might , that there was such a thing as daylight , but that it was made to be her enemy and destroyer , and she must always turn against it , for it had blighted you and would else blight her ; -- if you had done this , and then , for a purpose , had wanted her to take naturally to the daylight and she could not do it , you would have been disappointed and angry ? Parsing [sent. 6521 len. 60]: Miss Havisham 's intentions towards me , all a mere dream ; Estella not designed for me ; I only suffered in Satis House as a convenience , a sting for the greedy relations , a model with a mechanical heart to practise on when no other practice was at hand ; those were the first smarts I had .
Parsing [sent. 6522 len. 52]: But , sharpest and deepest pain of all , -- it was for the convict , guilty of I knew not what crimes , and liable to be taken out of those rooms where I sat thinking , and hanged at the Old Bailey door , that I had deserted Joe .
Parsing [sent. 6523 len. 45]: I would not have gone back to Joe now , I would not have gone back to Biddy now , for any consideration ; simply , I suppose , because my sense of my own worthless conduct to them was greater than every consideration .
Parsing [sent. 6524 len. 34]: No wisdom on earth could have given me the comfort that I should have derived from their simplicity and fidelity ; but I could never , never , undo what I had done .
Parsing [sent. 6525 len. 14]: In every rage of wind and rush of rain , I heard pursuers .
Parsing [sent. 6526 len. 17]: Twice , I could have sworn there was a knocking and whispering at the outer door .
Parsing [sent. 6527 len. 25]: With these fears upon me , I began either to imagine or recall that I had had mysterious warnings of this man 's approach .
Parsing [sent. 6528 len. 21]: That , for weeks gone by , I had passed faces in the streets which I had thought like his .
Parsing [sent. 6529 len. 20]: That these likenesses had grown more numerous , as he , coming over the sea , had drawn nearer .
Parsing [sent. 6530 len. 31]: That his wicked spirit had somehow sent these messengers to mine , and that now on this stormy night he was as good as his word , and with me .
Parsing [sent. 6531 len. 57]: Crowding up with these reflections came the reflection that I had seen him with my childish eyes to be a desperately violent man ; that I had heard that other convict reiterate that he had tried to murder him ; that I had seen him down in the ditch tearing and fighting like a wild beast .
Parsing [sent. 6532 len. 37]: Out of such remembrances I brought into the light of the fire a half-formed terror that it might not be safe to be shut up there with him in the dead of the wild solitary night .
Parsing [sent. 6533 len. 25]: This dilated until it filled the room , and impelled me to take a candle and go in and look at my dreadful burden .
Parsing [sent. 6534 len. 20]: He had rolled a handkerchief round his head , and his face was set and lowering in his sleep .
Parsing [sent. 6535 len. 19]: But he was asleep , and quietly too , though he had a pistol lying on the pillow .
Parsing [sent. 6536 len. 30]: Assured of this , I softly removed the key to the outside of his door , and turned it on him before I again sat down by the fire .
Parsing [sent. 6537 len. 12]: Gradually I slipped from the chair and lay on the floor .
Parsing [sent. 6538 len. 48]: When I awoke without having parted in my sleep with the perception of my wretchedness , the clocks of the Eastward churches were striking five , the candles were wasted out , the fire was dead , and the wind and rain intensified the thick black darkness .
Parsing [sent. 6539 len. 13]: THIS IS THE END OF THE SECOND STAGE OF PIP 'S EXPECTATIONS .
Parsing [sent. 6540 len. 51]: Chapter XL It was fortunate for me that I had to take precautions to ensure -LRB- so far as I could -RRB- the safety of my dreaded visitor ; for , this thought pressing on me when I awoke , held other thoughts in a confused concourse at a distance .
Parsing [sent. 6541 len. 12]: The impossibility of keeping him concealed in the chambers was self-evident .
Parsing [sent. 6542 len. 17]: It could not be done , and the attempt to do it would inevitably engender suspicion .
Parsing [sent. 6543 len. 49]: True , I had no Avenger in my service now , but I was looked after by an inflammatory old female , assisted by an animated rag-bag whom she called her niece , and to keep a room secret from them would be to invite curiosity and exaggeration .
Parsing [sent. 6544 len. 39]: They both had weak eyes , which I had long attributed to their chronically looking in at keyholes , and they were always at hand when not wanted ; indeed that was their only reliable quality besides larceny .
Parsing [sent. 6545 len. 27]: Not to get up a mystery with these people , I resolved to announce in the morning that my uncle had unexpectedly come from the country .
Parsing [sent. 6546 len. 22]: This course I decided on while I was yet groping about in the darkness for the means of getting a light .
Parsing [sent. 6547 len. 29]: Not stumbling on the means after all , I was fain to go out to the adjacent Lodge and get the watchman there to come with his lantern .
Parsing [sent. 6548 len. 26]: Now , in groping my way down the black staircase I fell over something , and that something was a man crouching in a corner .
Parsing [sent. 6549 len. 45]: As the man made no answer when I asked him what he did there , but eluded my touch in silence , I ran to the Lodge and urged the watchman to come quickly ; telling him of the incident on the way back .
Parsing [sent. 6550 len. 45]: The wind being as fierce as ever , we did not care to endanger the light in the lantern by rekindling the extinguished lamps on the staircase , but we examined the staircase from the bottom to the top and found no one there .
Parsing [sent. 6551 len. 51]: It then occurred to me as possible that the man might have slipped into my rooms ; so , lighting my candle at the watchman 's , and leaving him standing at the door , I examined them carefully , including the room in which my dreaded guest lay asleep .
Parsing [sent. 6552 len. 14]: All was quiet , and assuredly no other man was in those chambers .
Parsing [sent. 6553 len. 64]: It troubled me that there should have been a lurker on the stairs , on that night of all nights in the year , and I asked the watchman , on the chance of eliciting some hopeful explanation as I handed him a dram at the door , whether he had admitted at his gate any gentleman who had perceptibly been dining out ?
Parsing [sent. 6554 len. 14]: Yes , he said ; at different times of the night , three .
Parsing [sent. 6555 len. 24]: One lived in Fountain Court , and the other two lived in the Lane , and he had seen them all go home .
Parsing [sent. 6556 len. 53]: Again , the only other man who dwelt in the house of which my chambers formed a part had been in the country for some weeks , and he certainly had not returned in the night , because we had seen his door with his seal on it as we came up-stairs .
Parsing [sent. 6557 len. 32]: `` The night being so bad , sir , '' said the watchman , as he gave me back my glass , `` uncommon few have come in at my gate .
Parsing [sent. 6558 len. 29]: Besides them three gentlemen that I have named , I do n't call to mind another since about eleven o'clock , when a stranger asked for you . ''
Parsing [sent. 6559 len. 8]: `` My uncle , '' I muttered .

Parsing [sent. 6571 len. 25]: The watchman made more light of the matter than I did , and naturally ; not having my reason for attaching weight to it .
Parsing [sent. 6572 len. 31]: When I had got rid of him , which I thought it well to do without prolonging explanations , my mind was much troubled by these two circumstances taken together .
Parsing [sent. 6573 len. 91]: Whereas they were easy of innocent solution apart , -- as , for instance , some diner out or diner at home , who had not gone near this watchman 's gate , might have strayed to my staircase and dropped asleep there , -- and my nameless visitor might have brought some one with him to show him the way , -- still , joined , they had an ugly look to one as prone to distrust and fear as the changes of a few hours had made me .
Parsing [sent. 6574 len. 27]: I lighted my fire , which burnt with a raw pale flare at that time of the morning , and fell into a doze before it .
Parsing [sent. 6575 len. 15]: I seemed to have been dozing a whole night when the clocks struck six .
Parsing [sent. 6576 len. 64]: As there was full an hour and a half between me and daylight , I dozed again ; now , waking up uneasily , with prolix conversations about nothing , in my ears ; now , making thunder of the wind in the chimney ; at length , falling off into a profound sleep from which the daylight woke me with a start .
Parsing [sent. 6577 len. 21]: All this time I had never been able to consider my own situation , nor could I do so yet .
Parsing [sent. 6578 len. 10]: I had not the power to attend to it .
Parsing [sent. 6579 len. 16]: I was greatly dejected and distressed , but in an incoherent wholesale sort of way .
Parsing [sent. 6580 len. 18]: As to forming any plan for the future , I could as soon have formed an elephant .
Parsing [sent. 6581 len. 87]: When I opened the shutters and looked out at the wet wild morning , all of a leaden hue ; when I walked from room to room ; when I sat down again shivering , before the fire , waiting for my laundress to appear ; I thought how miserable I was , but hardly knew why , or how long I had been so , or on what day of the week I made the reflection , or even who I was that made it .
Parsing [sent. 6582 len. 38]: At last , the old woman and the niece came in , -- the latter with a head not easily distinguishable from her dusty broom , -- and testified surprise at sight of me and the fire .

Parsing [sent. 6785 len. 19]: To my thinking , there was something in him that made it hopeless to attempt to disguise him .
Parsing [sent. 6786 len. 24]: The more I dressed him and the better I dressed him , the more he looked like the slouching fugitive on the marshes .
Parsing [sent. 6787 len. 65]: This effect on my anxious fancy was partly referable , no doubt , to his old face and manner growing more familiar to me ; but I believe too that he dragged one of his legs as if there were still a weight of iron on it , and that from head to foot there was Convict in the very grain of the man .
Parsing [sent. 6788 len. 52]: The influences of his solitary hut-life were upon him besides , and gave him a savage air that no dress could tame ; added to these were the influences of his subsequent branded life among men , and , crowning all , his consciousness that he was dodging and hiding now .
Parsing [sent. 6789 len. 141]: In all his ways of sitting and standing , and eating and drinking , -- of brooding about in a high-shouldered reluctant style , -- of taking out his great horn-handled jackknife and wiping it on his legs and cutting his food , -- of lifting light glasses and cups to his lips , as if they were clumsy pannikins , -- of chopping a wedge off his bread , and soaking up with it the last fragments of gravy round and round his plate , as if to make the most of an allowance , and then drying his finger-ends on it , and then swallowing it , -- in these ways and a thousand other small nameless instances arising every minute in the day , there was Prisoner , Felon , Bondsman , plain as plain could be .
Parsing [sent. 6790 len. 24]: It had been his own idea to wear that touch of powder , and I had conceded the powder after overcoming the shorts .
Parsing [sent. 6791 len. 63]: But I can compare the effect of it , when on , to nothing but the probable effect of rouge upon the dead ; so awful was the manner in which everything in him that it was most desirable to repress , started through that thin layer of pretence , and seemed to come blazing out at the crown of his head .
Parsing [sent. 6792 len. 17]: It was abandoned as soon as tried , and he wore his grizzled hair cut short .
Parsing [sent. 6793 len. 25]: Words can not tell what a sense I had , at the same time , of the dreadful mystery that he was to me .
Parsing [sent. 6794 len. 73]: When he fell asleep of an evening , with his knotted hands clenching the sides of the easy-chair , and his bald head tattooed with deep wrinkles falling forward on his breast , I would sit and look at him , wondering what he had done , and loading him with all the crimes in the Calendar , until the impulse was powerful on me to start up and fly from him .
Parsing [sent. 6795 len. 53]: Every hour so increased my abhorrence of him , that I even think I might have yielded to this impulse in the first agonies of being so haunted , notwithstanding all he had done for me and the risk he ran , but for the knowledge that Herbert must soon come back .
Parsing [sent. 6796 len. 44]: Once , I actually did start out of bed in the night , and begin to dress myself in my worst clothes , hurriedly intending to leave him there with everything else I possessed , and enlist for India as a private soldier .
Parsing [sent. 6797 len. 36]: I doubt if a ghost could have been more terrible to me , up in those lonely rooms in the long evenings and long nights , with the wind and the rain always rushing by .
Parsing [sent. 6798 len. 37]: A ghost could not have been taken and hanged on my account , and the consideration that he could be , and the dread that he would be , were no small addition to my horrors .
Parsing [sent. 6799 len. 79]: When he was not asleep , or playing a complicated kind of Patience with a ragged pack of cards of his own , -- a game that I never saw before or since , and in which he recorded his winnings by sticking his jackknife into the table , -- when he was not engaged in either of these pursuits , he would ask me to read to him , -- `` Foreign language , dear boy ! Parsing [sent. 6957 len. 7]: There , you 've got it .

Parsing [sent. 6959 len. 14]: `` I 've been done everything to , pretty well -- except hanged .
Parsing [sent. 6960 len. 12]: I 've been locked up as much as a silver tea-kittle .
Parsing [sent. 6961 len. 36]: I 've been carted here and carted there , and put out of this town , and put out of that town , and stuck in the stocks , and whipped and worried and drove .
Parsing [sent. 6962 len. 17]: I 've no more notion where I was born than you have -- if so much .
Parsing [sent. 6963 len. 17]: I first become aware of myself down in Essex , a thieving turnips for my living .
Parsing [sent. 6964 len. 28]: Summun had run away from me -- a man -- a tinker -- and he 'd took the fire with him , and left me wery cold .
Parsing [sent. 6965 len. 14]: `` I know 'd my name to be Magwitch , chrisen 'd Abel .
Parsing [sent. 6966 len. 6]: How did I know it ?
Parsing [sent. 6967 len. 20]: Much as I know 'd the birds ' names in the hedges to be chaffinch , sparrer , thrush .
Parsing [sent. 6968 len. 25]: I might have thought it was all lies together , only as the birds ' names come out true , I supposed mine did .
Parsing [sent. 6969 len. 46]: `` So fur as I could find , there war n't a soul that see young Abel Magwitch , with us little on him as in him , but wot caught fright at him , and either drove him off , or took him up .

Parsing [sent. 6981 len. 45]: A deserting soldier in a Traveller 's Rest , what lay hid up to the chin under a lot of taturs , learnt me to read ; and a travelling Giant what signed his name at a penny a time learnt me to write .

Parsing [sent. 7411 len. 43]: Chapter XLV Turning from the Temple gate as soon as I had read the warning , I made the best of my way to Fleet Street , and there got a late hackney chariot and drove to the Hummums in Covent Garden .
Parsing [sent. 7412 len. 54]: In those times a bed was always to be got there at any hour of the night , and the chamberlain , letting me in at his ready wicket , lighted the candle next in order on his shelf , and showed me straight into the bedroom next in order on his list .
Parsing [sent. 7413 len. 59]: It was a sort of vault on the ground floor at the back , with a despotic monster of a four-post bedstead in it , straddling over the whole place , putting one of his arbitrary legs into the fireplace and another into the doorway , and squeezing the wretched little washing-stand in quite a Divinely Righteous manner .
Parsing [sent. 7414 len. 30]: As I had asked for a night-light , the chamberlain had brought me in , before he left me , the good old constitutional rushlight of those virtuous days .
Parsing [sent. 7415 len. 58]: -- an object like the ghost of a walking-cane , which instantly broke its back if it were touched , which nothing could ever be lighted at , and which was placed in solitary confinement at the bottom of a high tin tower , perforated with round holes that made a staringly wide-awake pattern on the walls .
Parsing [sent. 7416 len. 39]: When I had got into bed , and lay there footsore , weary , and wretched , I found that I could no more close my own eyes than I could close the eyes of this foolish Argus .
Parsing [sent. 7417 len. 18]: And thus , in the gloom and death of the night , we stared at one another .
Parsing [sent. 7418 len. 5]: What a doleful night !
Parsing [sent. 7419 len. 9]: How anxious , how dismal , how long !

Parsing [sent. 7615 len. 2]: Ahoy !
Parsing [sent. 7616 len. 4]: Bless you . ''
Parsing [sent. 7617 len. 56]: In this strain of consolation , Herbert informed me the invisible Barley would commune with himself by the day and night together ; Often , while it was light , having , at the same time , one eye at a telescope which was fitted on his bed for the convenience of sweeping the river .
Parsing [sent. 7618 len. 35]: In his two cabin rooms at the top of the house , which were fresh and airy , and in which Mr. Barley was less audible than below , I found Provis comfortably settled .
Parsing [sent. 7619 len. 48]: He expressed no alarm , and seemed to feel none that was worth mentioning ; but it struck me that he was softened , -- indefinably , for I could not have said how , and could never afterwards recall how when I tried , but certainly .
Parsing [sent. 7620 len. 26]: The opportunity that the day 's rest had given me for reflection had resulted in my fully determining to say nothing to him respecting Compeyson .
Parsing [sent. 7621 len. 25]: For anything I knew , his animosity towards the man might otherwise lead to his seeking him out and rushing on his own destruction .
Parsing [sent. 7622 len. 32]: Therefore , when Herbert and I sat down with him by his fire , I asked him first of all whether he relied on Wemmick 's judgment and sources of information ?
Parsing [sent. 7623 len. 9]: `` Ay , ay , dear boy ! ''
Parsing [sent. 7624 len. 13]: he answered , with a grave nod , `` Jaggers knows . ''
Parsing [sent. 7625 len. 30]: `` Then , I have talked with Wemmick , '' said I , `` and have come to tell you what caution he gave me and what advice . ''
Parsing [sent. 7626 len. 78]: This I did accurately , with the reservation just mentioned ; and I told him how Wemmick had heard , in Newgate prison -LRB- whether from officers or prisoners I could not say -RRB- , that he was under some suspicion , and that my chambers had been watched ; how Wemmick had recommended his keeping close for a time , and my keeping away from him ; and what Wemmick had said about getting him abroad .
Parsing [sent. 7627 len. 34]: I added , that of course , when the time came , I should go with him , or should follow close upon him , as might be safest in Wemmick 's judgment .
Parsing [sent. 7628 len. 47]: What was to follow that I did not touch upon ; neither , indeed , was I at all clear or comfortable about it in my own mind , now that I saw him in that softer condition , and in declared peril for my sake .
Parsing [sent. 7629 len. 39]: As to altering my way of living by enlarging my expenses , I put it to him whether in our present unsettled and difficult circumstances , it would not be simply ridiculous , if it were no worse ?
Parsing [sent. 7630 len. 13]: He could not deny this , and indeed was very reasonable throughout .
Parsing [sent. 7631 len. 21]: His coming back was a venture , he said , and he had always known it to be a venture .
Parsing [sent. 7632 len. 25]: He would do nothing to make it a desperate venture , and he had very little fear of his safety with such good help .
Parsing [sent. 7633 len. 37]: Herbert , who had been looking at the fire and pondering , here said that something had come into his thoughts arising out of Wemmick 's suggestion , which it might be worth while to pursue .
Parsing [sent. 7634 len. 23]: `` We are both good watermen , Handel , and could take him down the river ourselves when the right time comes .
Parsing [sent. 7635 len. 31]: No boat would then be hired for the purpose , and no boatmen ; that would save at least a chance of suspicion , and any chance is worth saving .
Parsing [sent. 7636 len. 42]: Never mind the season ; do n't you think it might be a good thing if you began at once to keep a boat at the Temple stairs , and were in the habit of rowing up and down the river ?
Parsing [sent. 7637 len. 13]: You fall into that habit , and then who notices or minds ?
Parsing [sent. 7638 len. 22]: Do it twenty or fifty times , and there is nothing special in your doing it the twenty-first or fifty-first . ''
Parsing [sent. 7639 len. 13]: I liked this scheme , and Provis was quite elated by it .
Parsing [sent. 7640 len. 30]: We agreed that it should be carried into execution , and that Provis should never recognize us if we came below Bridge , and rowed past Mill Pond Bank .
Parsing [sent. 7641 len. 32]: But we further agreed that he should pull down the blind in that part of his window which gave upon the east , whenever he saw us and all was right .
Parsing [sent. 7642 len. 42]: Our conference being now ended , and everything arranged , I rose to go ; remarking to Herbert that he and I had better not go home together , and that I would take half an hour 's start of him .
Parsing [sent. 7643 len. 30]: `` I do n't like to leave you here , '' I said to Provis , `` though I can not doubt your being safer here than near me .
Parsing [sent. 7644 len. 4]: Good by ! ''
Parsing [sent. 7645 len. 31]: `` Dear boy , '' he answered , clasping my hands , `` I do n't know when we may meet again , and I do n't like good by .
Parsing [sent. 7646 len. 5]: Say good night ! ''
Parsing [sent. 7647 len. 4]: `` Good night !
Parsing [sent. 7648 len. 21]: Herbert will go regularly between us , and when the time comes you may be certain I shall be ready .
Parsing [sent. 7649 len. 7]: Good night , good night ! ''
Parsing [sent. 7650 len. 36]: We thought it best that he should stay in his own rooms ; and we left him on the landing outside his door , holding a light over the stair-rail to light us down stairs .
Parsing [sent. 7651 len. 44]: Looking back at him , I thought of the first night of his return , when our positions were reversed , and when I little supposed my heart could ever be as heavy and anxious at parting from him as it was now .
Parsing [sent. 7652 len. 24]: Old Barley was growling and swearing when we repassed his door , with no appearance of having ceased or of meaning to cease .
Parsing [sent. 7653 len. 22]: When we got to the foot of the stairs , I asked Herbert whether he had preserved the name of Provis .
Parsing [sent. 7654 len. 14]: He replied , certainly not , and that the lodger was Mr. Campbell .
Parsing [sent. 7655 len. 44]: He also explained that the utmost known of Mr. Campbell there was , that he -LRB- Herbert -RRB- had Mr. Campbell consigned to him , and felt a strong personal interest in his being well cared for , and living a secluded life .
Parsing [sent. 7656 len. 35]: So , when we went into the parlor where Mrs. Whimple and Clara were seated at work , I said nothing of my own interest in Mr. Campbell , but kept it to myself .
Parsing [sent. 7657 len. 50]: When I had taken leave of the pretty , gentle , dark-eyed girl , and of the motherly woman who had not outlived her honest sympathy with a little affair of true love , I felt as if the Old Green Copper Ropewalk had grown quite a different place .
Parsing [sent. 7658 len. 40]: Old Barley might be as old as the hills , and might swear like a whole field of troopers , but there were redeeming youth and trust and hope enough in Chinks 's Basin to fill it to overflowing .
Parsing [sent. 7659 len. 18]: And then I thought of Estella , and of our parting , and went home very sadly .
Parsing [sent. 7660 len. 15]: All things were as quiet in the Temple as ever I had seen them .
Parsing [sent. 7661 len. 28]: The windows of the rooms on that side , lately occupied by Provis , were dark and still , and there was no lounger in Garden Court .
Parsing [sent. 7662 len. 27]: I walked past the fountain twice or thrice before I descended the steps that were between me and my rooms , but I was quite alone .
Parsing [sent. 7663 len. 29]: Herbert , coming to my bedside when he came in , -- for I went straight to bed , dispirited and fatigued , -- made the same report .
Parsing [sent. 7664 len. 36]: Opening one of the windows after that , he looked out into the moonlight , and told me that the pavement was a solemnly empty as the pavement of any cathedral at that same hour .
Parsing [sent. 7665 len. 10]: Next day I set myself to get the boat .
Parsing [sent. 7666 len. 29]: It was soon done , and the boat was brought round to the Temple stairs , and lay where I could reach her within a minute or two .
Parsing [sent. 7667 len. 20]: Then , I began to go out as for training and practice : sometimes alone , sometimes with Herbert .
Parsing [sent. 7668 len. 28]: I was often out in cold , rain , and sleet , but nobody took much note of me after I had been out a few times .
Parsing [sent. 7669 len. 24]: At first , I kept above Blackfriars Bridge ; but as the hours of the tide changed , I took towards London Bridge .
Parsing [sent. 7670 len. 32]: It was Old London Bridge in those days , and at certain states of the tide there was a race and fall of water there which gave it a bad reputation .
Parsing [sent. 7671 len. 35]: But I knew well enough how to `` shoot ' the bridge after seeing it done , and so began to row about among the shipping in the Pool , and down to Erith .
Parsing [sent. 7672 len. 37]: The first time I passed Mill Pond Bank , Herbert and I were pulling a pair of oars ; and , both in going and returning , we saw the blind towards the east come down .
Parsing [sent. 7673 len. 29]: Herbert was rarely there less frequently than three times in a week , and he never brought me a single word of intelligence that was at all alarming .
Parsing [sent. 7674 len. 24]: Still , I knew that there was cause for alarm , and I could not get rid of the notion of being watched .
Parsing [sent. 7675 len. 26]: Once received , it is a haunting idea ; how many undesigning persons I suspected of watching me , it would be hard to calculate .
Parsing [sent. 7676 len. 18]: In short , I was always full of fears for the rash man who was in hiding .
Parsing [sent. 7677 len. 44]: Herbert had sometimes said to me that he found it pleasant to stand at one of our windows after dark , when the tide was running down , and to think that it was flowing , with everything it bore , towards Clara .
Parsing [sent. 7678 len. 37]: But I thought with dread that it was flowing towards Magwitch , and that any black mark on its surface might be his pursuers , going swiftly , silently , and surely , to take him .
Parsing [sent. 7679 len. 10]: Chapter XLVII Some weeks passed without bringing any change .
Parsing [sent. 7680 len. 11]: We waited for Wemmick , and he made no sign .
Parsing [sent. 7681 len. 45]: If I had never known him out of Little Britain , and had never enjoyed the privilege of being on a familiar footing at the Castle , I might have doubted him ; not so for a moment , knowing him as I did .
Parsing [sent. 7682 len. 22]: My worldly affairs began to wear a gloomy appearance , and I was pressed for money by more than one creditor .
Parsing [sent. 7683 len. 37]: Even I myself began to know the want of money -LRB- I mean of ready money in my own pocket -RRB- , and to relieve it by converting some easily spared articles of jewelery into cash .
Parsing [sent. 7684 len. 30]: But I had quite determined that it would be a heartless fraud to take more money from my patron in the existing state of my uncertain thoughts and plans .
Parsing [sent. 7685 len. 54]: Therefore , I had sent him the unopened pocket-book by Herbert , to hold in his own keeping , and I felt a kind of satisfaction -- whether it was a false kind or a true , I hardly know -- in not having profited by his generosity since his revelation of himself .
Parsing [sent. 7686 len. 17]: As the time wore on , an impression settled heavily upon me that Estella was married .
Parsing [sent. 7687 len. 43]: Fearful of having it confirmed , though it was all but a conviction , I avoided the newspapers , and begged Herbert -LRB- to whom I had confided the circumstances of our last interview -RRB- never to speak of her to me .
Parsing [sent. 7688 len. 28]: Why I hoarded up this last wretched little rag of the robe of hope that was rent and given to the winds , how do I know ?
Parsing [sent. 7689 len. 24]: Why did you who read this , commit that not dissimilar inconsistency of your own last year , last month , last week ?
Parsing [sent. 7690 len. 38]: It was an unhappy life that I lived ; and its one dominant anxiety , towering over all its other anxieties , like a high mountain above a range of mountains , never disappeared from my view .
Parsing [sent. 7691 len. 9]: Still , no new cause for fear arose .
Parsing [sent. 7692 len. 73]: Let me start from my bed as I would , with the terror fresh upon me that he was discovered ; let me sit listening , as I would with dread , for Herbert 's returning step at night , lest it should be fleeter than ordinary , and winged with evil news , -- for all that , and much more to like purpose , the round of things went on .
Parsing [sent. 7693 len. 31]: Condemned to inaction and a state of constant restlessness and suspense , I rowed about in my boat , and waited , waited , waited , as I best could .
Parsing [sent. 7694 len. 54]: There were states of the tide when , having been down the river , I could not get back through the eddy-chafed arches and starlings of old London Bridge ; then , I left my boat at a wharf near the Custom House , to be brought up afterwards to the Temple stairs .
Parsing [sent. 7695 len. 26]: I was not averse to doing this , as it served to make me and my boat a commoner incident among the water-side people there .
Parsing [sent. 7696 len. 15]: From this slight occasion sprang two meetings that I have now to tell of .
Parsing [sent. 7697 len. 19]: One afternoon , late in the month of February , I came ashore at the wharf at dusk .
Parsing [sent. 7698 len. 20]: I had pulled down as far as Greenwich with the ebb tide , and had turned with the tide .
Parsing [sent. 7699 len. 33]: It had been a fine bright day , but had become foggy as the sun dropped , and I had had to feel my way back among the shipping , pretty carefully .
Parsing [sent. 7700 len. 18]: Both in going and returning , I had seen the signal in his window , All well .
Parsing [sent. 7701 len. 52]: As it was a raw evening , and I was cold , I thought I would comfort myself with dinner at once ; and as I had hours of dejection and solitude before me if I went home to the Temple , I thought I would afterwards go to the play .
Parsing [sent. 7702 len. 31]: The theatre where Mr. Wopsle had achieved his questionable triumph was in that water-side neighborhood -LRB- it is nowhere now -RRB- , and to that theatre I resolved to go .
Parsing [sent. 7703 len. 27]: I was aware that Mr. Wopsle had not succeeded in reviving the Drama , but , on the contrary , had rather partaken of its decline .
Parsing [sent. 7704 len. 30]: He had been ominously heard of , through the play-bills , as a faithful Black , in connection with a little girl of noble birth , and a monkey .
Parsing [sent. 7705 len. 29]: And Herbert had seen him as a predatory Tartar of comic propensities , with a face like a red brick , and an outrageous hat all over bells .
Parsing [sent. 7706 len. 87]: I dined at what Herbert and I used to call a geographical chop-house , where there were maps of the world in porter-pot rims on every half-yard of the tablecloths , and charts of gravy on every one of the knives , -- to this day there is scarcely a single chop-house within the Lord Mayor 's dominions which is not geographical , -- and wore out the time in dozing over crumbs , staring at gas , and baking in a hot blast of dinners .
Parsing [sent. 7707 len. 14]: By and by , I roused myself , and went to the play .
Parsing [sent. 7708 len. 80]: There , I found a virtuous boatswain in His Majesty 's service , -- a most excellent man , though I could have wished his trousers not quite so tight in some places , and not quite so loose in others , -- who knocked all the little men 's hats over their eyes , though he was very generous and brave , and who would n't hear of anybody 's paying taxes , though he was very patriotic .
Parsing [sent. 7709 len. 70]: He had a bag of money in his pocket , like a pudding in the cloth , and on that property married a young person in bed-furniture , with great rejoicings ; the whole population of Portsmouth -LRB- nine in number at the last census -RRB- turning out on the beach to rub their own hands and shake everybody else 's , and sing `` Fill , fill ! ''
Parsing [sent. 7710 len. 138]: A certain dark-complexioned Swab , however , who would n't fill , or do anything else that was proposed to him , and whose heart was openly stated -LRB- by the boatswain -RRB- to be as black as his figure-head , proposed to two other Swabs to get all mankind into difficulties ; which was so effectually done -LRB- the Swab family having considerable political influence -RRB- that it took half the evening to set things right , and then it was only brought about through an honest little grocer with a white hat , black gaiters , and red nose , getting into a clock , with a gridiron , and listening , and coming out , and knocking everybody down from behind with the gridiron whom he could n't confute with what he had overheard .
Parsing [sent. 7711 len. 71]: This led to Mr. Wopsle 's -LRB- who had never been heard of before -RRB- coming in with a star and garter on , as a plenipotentiary of great power direct from the Admiralty , to say that the Swabs were all to go to prison on the spot , and that he had brought the boatswain down the Union Jack , as a slight acknowledgment of his public services .
Parsing [sent. 7712 len. 39]: The boatswain , unmanned for the first time , respectfully dried his eyes on the Jack , and then cheering up , and addressing Mr. Wopsle as Your Honor , solicited permission to take him by the fin .
Parsing [sent. 7713 len. 43]: Mr. Wopsle , conceding his fin with a gracious dignity , was immediately shoved into a dusty corner , while everybody danced a hornpipe ; and from that corner , surveying the public with a discontented eye , became aware of me .
Parsing [sent. 7714 len. 76]: The second piece was the last new grand comic Christmas pantomime , in the first scene of which , it pained me to suspect that I detected Mr. Wopsle with red worsted legs under a highly magnified phosphoric countenance and a shock of red curtain-fringe for his hair , engaged in the manufacture of thunderbolts in a mine , and displaying great cowardice when his gigantic master came home -LRB- very hoarse -RRB- to dinner .
Parsing [sent. 7715 len. 104]: But he presently presented himself under worthier circumstances ; for , the Genius of Youthful Love being in want of assistance , -- on account of the parental brutality of an ignorant farmer who opposed the choice of his daughter 's heart , by purposely falling upon the object , in a flour-sack , out of the first-floor window , -- summoned a sententious Enchanter ; and he , coming up from the antipodes rather unsteadily , after an apparently violent journey , proved to be Mr. Wopsle in a high-crowned hat , with a necromantic work in one volume under his arm .
Parsing [sent. 7716 len. 43]: The business of this enchanter on earth being principally to be talked at , sung at , butted at , danced at , and flashed at with fires of various colors , he had a good deal of time on his hands .
Parsing [sent. 7717 len. 25]: And I observed , with great surprise , that he devoted it to staring in my direction as if he were lost in amazement .
Parsing [sent. 7718 len. 42]: There was something so remarkable in the increasing glare of Mr. Wopsle 's eye , and he seemed to be turning so many things over in his mind and to grow so confused , that I could not make it out .
Parsing [sent. 7719 len. 27]: I sat thinking of it long after he had ascended to the clouds in a large watch-case , and still I could not make it out .
Parsing [sent. 7720 len. 27]: I was still thinking of it when I came out of the theatre an hour afterwards , and found him waiting for me near the door .
Parsing [sent. 7721 len. 7]: `` How do you do ? ''
Parsing [sent. 7722 len. 15]: said I , shaking hands with him as we turned down the street together .
Parsing [sent. 7723 len. 9]: `` I saw that you saw me . ''
Parsing [sent. 7724 len. 8]: `` Saw you , Mr. Pip ! ''
Parsing [sent. 7725 len. 3]: he returned .
Parsing [sent. 7726 len. 9]: `` Yes , of course I saw you .
Parsing [sent. 7727 len. 7]: But who else was there ? ''
Parsing [sent. 7728 len. 5]: `` Who else ? ''
Parsing [sent. 7729 len. 29]: `` It is the strangest thing , '' said Mr. Wopsle , drifting into his lost look again ; `` and yet I could swear to him . ''
Parsing [sent. 7730 len. 12]: Becoming alarmed , I entreated Mr. Wopsle to explain his meaning .
Parsing [sent. 7731 len. 42]: `` Whether I should have noticed him at first but for your being there , '' said Mr. Wopsle , going on in the same lost way , `` I ca n't be positive ; yet I think I should . ''
Parsing [sent. 7732 len. 28]: Involuntarily I looked round me , as I was accustomed to look round me when I went home ; for these mysterious words gave me a chill .
Parsing [sent. 7733 len. 3]: `` Oh !
Parsing [sent. 7734 len. 12]: He ca n't be in sight , '' said Mr. Wopsle .
Parsing [sent. 7735 len. 9]: `` He went out before I went off .
Parsing [sent. 7736 len. 6]: I saw him go . ''
Parsing [sent. 7737 len. 17]: Having the reason that I had for being suspicious , I even suspected this poor actor .
Parsing [sent. 7738 len. 11]: I mistrusted a design to entrap me into some admission .
Parsing [sent. 7739 len. 15]: Therefore I glanced at him as we walked on together , but said nothing .
Parsing [sent. 7740 len. 36]: `` I had a ridiculous fancy that he must be with you , Mr. Pip , till I saw that you were quite unconscious of him , sitting behind you there like a ghost . ''
Parsing [sent. 7741 len. 41]: My former chill crept over me again , but I was resolved not to speak yet , for it was quite consistent with his words that he might be set on to induce me to connect these references with Provis .
Parsing [sent. 7742 len. 16]: Of course , I was perfectly sure and safe that Provis had not been there .
Parsing [sent. 7743 len. 19]: `` I dare say you wonder at me , Mr. Pip ; indeed , I see you do .
Parsing [sent. 7744 len. 7]: But it is so very strange !
Parsing [sent. 7745 len. 12]: You 'll hardly believe what I am going to tell you .
Parsing [sent. 7746 len. 13]: I could hardly believe it myself , if you told me . ''
Parsing [sent. 7747 len. 4]: `` Indeed ? ''
Parsing [sent. 7748 len. 7]: said I. `` No , indeed .
Parsing [sent. 7749 len. 43]: Mr. Pip , you remember in old times a certain Christmas Day , when you were quite a child , and I dined at Gargery 's , and some soldiers came to the door to get a pair of handcuffs mended ? ''
Parsing [sent. 7750 len. 8]: `` I remember it very well . ''
Parsing [sent. 7751 len. 49]: `` And you remember that there was a chase after two convicts , and that we joined in it , and that Gargery took you on his back , and that I took the lead , and you kept up with me as well as you could ? ''
Parsing [sent. 7752 len. 9]: `` I remember it all very well . ''
Parsing [sent. 7753 len. 11]: Better than he thought , -- except the last clause .
Parsing [sent. 7754 len. 44]: `` And you remember that we came up with the two in a ditch , and that there was a scuffle between them , and that one of them had been severely handled and much mauled about the face by the other ? ''
Parsing [sent. 7755 len. 9]: `` I see it all before me . ''
Parsing [sent. 7756 len. 71]: `` And that the soldiers lighted torches , and put the two in the centre , and that we went on to see the last of them , over the black marshes , with the torchlight shining on their faces , -- I am particular about that , -- with the torchlight shining on their faces , when there was an outer ring of dark night all about us ? ''
Parsing [sent. 7757 len. 13]: `` Yes , '' said I. `` I remember all that . ''
Parsing [sent. 7758 len. 16]: `` Then , Mr. Pip , one of those two prisoners sat behind you tonight .
Parsing [sent. 7759 len. 8]: I saw him over your shoulder . ''
Parsing [sent. 7760 len. 4]: `` Steady ! ''
Parsing [sent. 7761 len. 3]: I thought .
Parsing [sent. 7762 len. 17]: I asked him then , `` Which of the two do you suppose you saw ? ''
Parsing [sent. 7763 len. 22]: `` The one who had been mauled , '' he answered readily , `` and I 'll swear I saw him !
Parsing [sent. 7764 len. 16]: The more I think of him , the more certain I am of him . ''
Parsing [sent. 7765 len. 7]: `` This is very curious ! ''
Parsing [sent. 7766 len. 19]: said I , with the best assumption I could put on of its being nothing more to me .
Parsing [sent. 7767 len. 6]: `` Very curious indeed ! ''
Parsing [sent. 7768 len. 35]: I can not exaggerate the enhanced disquiet into which this conversation threw me , or the special and peculiar terror I felt at Compeyson 's having been behind me `` like a ghost . ''
Parsing [sent. 7769 len. 77]: For if he had ever been out of my thoughts for a few moments together since the hiding had begun , it was in those very moments when he was closest to me ; and to think that I should be so unconscious and off my guard after all my care was as if I had shut an avenue of a hundred doors to keep him out , and then had found him at my elbow .
Parsing [sent. 7770 len. 39]: I could not doubt , either , that he was there , because I was there , and that , however slight an appearance of danger there might be about us , danger was always near and active .
Parsing [sent. 7771 len. 16]: I put such questions to Mr. Wopsle as , When did the man come in ?
Parsing [sent. 7772 len. 20]: He could not tell me that ; he saw me , and over my shoulder he saw the man .
Parsing [sent. 7773 len. 44]: It was not until he had seen him for some time that he began to identify him ; but he had from the first vaguely associated him with me , and known him as somehow belonging to me in the old village time .
Parsing [sent. 7774 len. 5]: How was he dressed ?
Parsing [sent. 7775 len. 13]: Prosperously , but not noticeably otherwise ; he thought , in black .
Parsing [sent. 7776 len. 7]: Was his face at all disfigured ?
Parsing [sent. 7777 len. 6]: No , he believed not .
Parsing [sent. 7778 len. 40]: I believed not too , for , although in my brooding state I had taken no especial notice of the people behind me , I thought it likely that a face at all disfigured would have attracted my attention .
Parsing [sent. 7779 len. 38]: When Mr. Wopsle had imparted to me all that he could recall or I extract , and when I had treated him to a little appropriate refreshment , after the fatigues of the evening , we parted .
Parsing [sent. 7780 len. 19]: It was between twelve and one o'clock when I reached the Temple , and the gates were shut .
Parsing [sent. 7781 len. 13]: No one was near me when I went in and went home .
Parsing [sent. 7782 len. 16]: Herbert had come in , and we held a very serious council by the fire .
Parsing [sent. 7783 len. 32]: But there was nothing to be done , saving to communicate to Wemmick what I had that night found out , and to remind him that we waited for his hint .
Parsing [sent. 7784 len. 24]: As I thought that I might compromise him if I went too often to the Castle , I made this communication by letter .
Parsing [sent. 7785 len. 24]: I wrote it before I went to bed , and went out and posted it ; and again no one was near me .
Parsing [sent. 7786 len. 15]: Herbert and I agreed that we could do nothing else but be very cautious .
Parsing [sent. 7787 len. 53]: And we were very cautious indeed , -- more cautious than before , if that were possible , -- and I for my part never went near Chinks 's Basin , except when I rowed by , and then I only looked at Mill Pond Bank as I looked at anything else .
Parsing [sent. 7788 len. 22]: Chapter XLVIII The second of the two meetings referred to in the last chapter occurred about a week after the first .
Parsing [sent. 7789 len. 68]: I had again left my boat at the wharf below Bridge ; the time was an hour earlier in the afternoon ; and , undecided where to dine , I had strolled up into Cheapside , and was strolling along it , surely the most unsettled person in all the busy concourse , when a large hand was laid upon my shoulder by some one overtaking me .
Parsing [sent. 7790 len. 15]: It was Mr. Jaggers 's hand , and he passed it through my arm .
Parsing [sent. 7791 len. 17]: `` As we are going in the same direction , Pip , we may walk together .
Parsing [sent. 7792 len. 7]: Where are you bound for ? ''
Parsing [sent. 7793 len. 18]: `` For the Temple , I think , '' said I. `` Do n't you know ? ''
Parsing [sent. 7794 len. 4]: said Mr. Jaggers .
Parsing [sent. 7795 len. 35]: `` Well , '' I returned , glad for once to get the better of him in cross-examination , `` I do not know , for I have not made up my mind . ''
Parsing [sent. 7796 len. 8]: `` You are going to dine ? ''
Parsing [sent. 7797 len. 4]: said Mr. Jaggers .
Parsing [sent. 7798 len. 12]: `` You do n't mind admitting that , I suppose ? ''
Parsing [sent. 7799 len. 16]: `` No , '' I returned , `` I do n't mind admitting that . ''
Parsing [sent. 7800 len. 7]: `` And are not engaged ? ''
Parsing [sent. 7801 len. 14]: `` I do n't mind admitting also that I am not engaged . ''
Parsing [sent. 7802 len. 16]: `` Then , '' said Mr. Jaggers , `` come and dine with me . ''
Parsing [sent. 7803 len. 17]: I was going to excuse myself , when he added , `` Wemmick 's coming . ''
Parsing [sent. 7804 len. 107]: So I changed my excuse into an acceptance , -- the few words I had uttered , serving for the beginning of either , -- and we went along Cheapside and slanted off to Little Britain , while the lights were springing up brilliantly in the shop windows , and the street lamp-lighters , scarcely finding ground enough to plant their ladders on in the midst of the afternoon 's bustle , were skipping up and down and running in and out , opening more red eyes in the gathering fog than my rushlight tower at the Hummums had opened white eyes in the ghostly wall .

Parsing [sent. 8022 len. 41]: I entreated her to rise , and got my arms about her to help her up ; but she only pressed that hand of mine which was nearest to her grasp , and hung her head over it and wept .
Parsing [sent. 8023 len. 30]: I had never seen her shed a tear before , and , in the hope that the relief might do her good , I bent over her without speaking .
Parsing [sent. 8024 len. 13]: She was not kneeling now , but was down upon the ground .
Parsing [sent. 8025 len. 4]: `` O ! ''
Parsing [sent. 8026 len. 5]: she cried , despairingly .
Parsing [sent. 8027 len. 6]: `` What have I done !
Parsing [sent. 8028 len. 6]: What have I done ! ''
Parsing [sent. 8029 len. 20]: `` If you mean , Miss Havisham , what have you done to injure me , let me answer .
Parsing [sent. 8030 len. 3]: Very little .
Parsing [sent. 8031 len. 9]: I should have loved her under any circumstances .
Parsing [sent. 8032 len. 5]: Is she married ? ''
Parsing [sent. 8033 len. 4]: `` Yes . ''
Parsing [sent. 8034 len. 19]: It was a needless question , for a new desolation in the desolate house had told me so .
Parsing [sent. 8035 len. 6]: `` What have I done !
Parsing [sent. 8036 len. 6]: What have I done ! ''
Parsing [sent. 8037 len. 21]: She wrung her hands , and crushed her white hair , and returned to this cry over and over again .
Parsing [sent. 8038 len. 7]: `` What have I done ! ''
Parsing [sent. 8039 len. 13]: I knew not how to answer , or how to comfort her .
Parsing [sent. 8040 len. 37]: That she had done a grievous thing in taking an impressionable child to mould into the form that her wild resentment , spurned affection , and wounded pride found vengeance in , I knew full well .
Parsing [sent. 8041 len. 69]: But that , in shutting out the light of day , she had shut out infinitely more ; that , in seclusion , she had secluded herself from a thousand natural and healing influences ; that , her mind , brooding solitary , had grown diseased , as all minds do and must and will that reverse the appointed order of their Maker , I knew equally well .
Parsing [sent. 8042 len. 71]: And could I look upon her without compassion , seeing her punishment in the ruin she was , in her profound unfitness for this earth on which she was placed , in the vanity of sorrow which had become a master mania , like the vanity of penitence , the vanity of remorse , the vanity of unworthiness , and other monstrous vanities that have been curses in this world ?
Parsing [sent. 8043 len. 36]: `` Until you spoke to her the other day , and until I saw in you a looking-glass that showed me what I once felt myself , I did not know what I had done .
Parsing [sent. 8044 len. 5]: What have I done !
Parsing [sent. 8045 len. 6]: What have I done ! ''
Parsing [sent. 8046 len. 15]: And so again , twenty , fifty times over , What had she done !
Parsing [sent. 8047 len. 26]: `` Miss Havisham , '' I said , when her cry had died away , `` you may dismiss me from your mind and conscience .
Parsing [sent. 8048 len. 51]: But Estella is a different case , and if you can ever undo any scrap of what you have done amiss in keeping a part of her right nature away from her , it will be better to do that than to bemoan the past through a hundred years . ''
Parsing [sent. 8049 len. 9]: `` Yes , yes , I know it .
Parsing [sent. 8050 len. 8]: But , Pip -- my dear ! ''
Parsing [sent. 8051 len. 13]: There was an earnest womanly compassion for me in her new affection .
Parsing [sent. 8052 len. 4]: `` My dear !
Parsing [sent. 8053 len. 21]: Believe this : when she first came to me , I meant to save her from misery like my own .
Parsing [sent. 8054 len. 9]: At first , I meant no more . ''
Parsing [sent. 8055 len. 6]: `` Well , well ! ''
Parsing [sent. 8056 len. 8]: said I. `` I hope so . ''
Parsing [sent. 8057 len. 66]: `` But as she grew , and promised to be very beautiful , I gradually did worse , and with my praises , and with my jewels , and with my teachings , and with this figure of myself always before her , a warning to back and point my lessons , I stole her heart away , and put ice in its place . ''
Parsing [sent. 8058 len. 27]: `` Better , '' I could not help saying , `` to have left her a natural heart , even to be bruised or broken . ''
Parsing [sent. 8059 len. 24]: With that , Miss Havisham looked distractedly at me for a while , and then burst out again , What had she done !
Parsing [sent. 8060 len. 28]: `` If you knew all my story , '' she pleaded , `` you would have some compassion for me and a better understanding of me . ''
Parsing [sent. 8061 len. 39]: `` Miss Havisham , '' I answered , as delicately as I could , `` I believe I may say that I do know your story , and have known it ever since I first left this neighborhood .

Parsing [sent. 8065 len. 22]: She was seated on the ground , with her arms on the ragged chair , and her head leaning on them .
Parsing [sent. 8066 len. 18]: She looked full at me when I said this , and replied , `` Go on . ''

Parsing [sent. 8068 len. 5]: She shook her head .

Parsing [sent. 8075 len. 33]: I had first seen him when I sent for him to lay this place waste for me ; having read of him in the newspapers , before I and the world parted .
Parsing [sent. 8076 len. 15]: He told me that he would look about him for such an orphan child .

Parsing [sent. 8081 len. 26]: So convinced I was of that woman 's being her mother , that I wanted no evidence to establish the fact in my own mind .

Parsing [sent. 8085 len. 12]: No matter with what other words we parted ; we parted .
Parsing [sent. 8086 len. 14]: Twilight was closing in when I went down stairs into the natural air .

Parsing [sent. 8088 len. 29]: For I had a presentiment that I should never be there again , and I felt that the dying light was suited to my last view of it .
Parsing [sent. 8089 len. 54]: By the wilderness of casks that I had walked on long ago , and on which the rain of years had fallen since , rotting them in many places , and leaving miniature swamps and pools of water upon those that stood on end , I made my way to the ruined garden .
Parsing [sent. 8090 len. 30]: I went all round it ; round by the corner where Herbert and I had fought our battle ; round by the paths where Estella and I had walked .
Parsing [sent. 8091 len. 10]: So cold , so lonely , so dreary all !
Parsing [sent. 8092 len. 28]: Taking the brewery on my way back , I raised the rusty latch of a little door at the garden end of it , and walked through .
Parsing [sent. 8093 len. 52]: I was going out at the opposite door , -- not easy to open now , for the damp wood had started and swelled , and the hinges were yielding , and the threshold was encumbered with a growth of fungus , -- when I turned my head to look back .
Parsing [sent. 8094 len. 28]: A childish association revived with wonderful force in the moment of the slight action , and I fancied that I saw Miss Havisham hanging to the beam .
Parsing [sent. 8095 len. 37]: So strong was the impression , that I stood under the beam shuddering from head to foot before I knew it was a fancy , -- though to be sure I was there in an instant .
Parsing [sent. 8096 len. 52]: The mournfulness of the place and time , and the great terror of this illusion , though it was but momentary , caused me to feel an indescribable awe as I came out between the open wooden gates where I had once wrung my hair after Estella had wrung my heart .
Parsing [sent. 8097 len. 52]: Passing on into the front courtyard , I hesitated whether to call the woman to let me out at the locked gate of which she had the key , or first to go up stairs and assure myself that Miss Havisham was as safe and well as I had left her .
Parsing [sent. 8098 len. 9]: I took the latter course and went up .
Parsing [sent. 8099 len. 34]: I looked into the room where I had left her , and I saw her seated in the ragged chair upon the hearth close to the fire , with her back towards me .
Parsing [sent. 8100 len. 23]: In the moment when I was withdrawing my head to go quietly away , I saw a great flaming light spring up .
Parsing [sent. 8101 len. 38]: In the same moment I saw her running at me , shrieking , with a whirl of fire blazing all about her , and soaring at least as many feet above her head as she was high .
Parsing [sent. 8102 len. 15]: I had a double-caped great-coat on , and over my arm another thick coat .
Parsing [sent. 8103 len. 111]: That I got them off , closed with her , threw her down , and got them over her ; that I dragged the great cloth from the table for the same purpose , and with it dragged down the heap of rottenness in the midst , and all the ugly things that sheltered there ; that we were on the ground struggling like desperate enemies , and that the closer I covered her , the more wildly she shrieked and tried to free herself , -- that this occurred I knew through the result , but not through anything I felt , or thought , or knew I did .
Parsing [sent. 8104 len. 44]: I knew nothing until I knew that we were on the floor by the great table , and that patches of tinder yet alight were floating in the smoky air , which , a moment ago , had been her faded bridal dress .
Parsing [sent. 8105 len. 30]: Then , I looked round and saw the disturbed beetles and spiders running away over the floor , and the servants coming in with breathless cries at the door .
Parsing [sent. 8106 len. 74]: I still held her forcibly down with all my strength , like a prisoner who might escape ; and I doubt if I even knew who she was , or why we had struggled , or that she had been in flames , or that the flames were out , until I saw the patches of tinder that had been her garments no longer alight but falling in a black shower around us .
Parsing [sent. 8107 len. 17]: She was insensible , and I was afraid to have her moved , or even touched .
Parsing [sent. 8108 len. 42]: Assistance was sent for , and I held her until it came , as if I unreasonably fancied -LRB- I think I did -RRB- that , if I let her go , the fire would break out again and consume her .

Parsing [sent. 8110 len. 31]: On examination it was pronounced that she had received serious hurts , but that they of themselves were far from hopeless ; the danger lay mainly in the nervous shock .

Parsing [sent. 8112 len. 36]: When I saw her again , an hour afterwards , she lay , indeed , where I had seen her strike her stick , and had heard her say that she would lie one day .
Parsing [sent. 8113 len. 66]: Though every vestige of her dress was burnt , as they told me , she still had something of her old ghastly bridal appearance ; for , they had covered her to the throat with white cotton-wool , and as she lay with a white sheet loosely overlying that , the phantom air of something that had been and was changed was still upon her .

Parsing [sent. 8228 len. 26]: Chapter LI What purpose I had in view when I was hot on tracing out and proving Estella 's parentage , I can not say .

Parsing [sent. 8230 len. 53]: But when Herbert and I had held our momentous conversation , I was seized with a feverish conviction that I ought to hunt the matter down , -- that I ought not to let it rest , but that I ought to see Mr. Jaggers , and come at the bare truth .
Parsing [sent. 8231 len. 48]: I really do not know whether I felt that I did this for Estella 's sake , or whether I was glad to transfer to the man in whose preservation I was so much concerned some rays of the romantic interest that had so long surrounded me .
Parsing [sent. 8232 len. 12]: Perhaps the latter possibility may be the nearer to the truth .
Parsing [sent. 8233 len. 17]: Any way , I could scarcely be withheld from going out to Gerrard Street that night .
Parsing [sent. 8234 len. 34]: Herbert 's representations that , if I did , I should probably be laid up and stricken useless , when our fugitive 's safety would depend upon me , alone restrained my impatience .
Parsing [sent. 8235 len. 46]: On the understanding , again and again reiterated , that , come what would , I was to go to Mr. Jaggers to-morrow , I at length submitted to keep quiet , and to have my hurts looked after , and to stay at home .
Parsing [sent. 8236 len. 37]: Early next morning we went out together , and at the corner of Giltspur Street by Smithfield , I left Herbert to go his way into the City , and took my way to Little Britain .
Parsing [sent. 8237 len. 27]: There were periodical occasions when Mr. Jaggers and Wemmick went over the office accounts , and checked off the vouchers , and put all things straight .
Parsing [sent. 8238 len. 29]: On these occasions , Wemmick took his books and papers into Mr. Jaggers 's room , and one of the up-stairs clerks came down into the outer office .
Parsing [sent. 8239 len. 45]: Finding such clerk on Wemmick 's post that morning , I knew what was going on ; but I was not sorry to have Mr. Jaggers and Wemmick together , as Wemmick would then hear for himself that I said nothing to compromise him .
Parsing [sent. 8240 len. 19]: My appearance , with my arm bandaged and my coat loose over my shoulders , favored my object .
Parsing [sent. 8241 len. 64]: Although I had sent Mr. Jaggers a brief account of the accident as soon as I had arrived in town , yet I had to give him all the details now ; and the speciality of the occasion caused our talk to be less dry and hard , and less strictly regulated by the rules of evidence , than it had been before .

Parsing [sent. 8419 len. 46]: It had seemed to me , in the many anxious considerations I had given the point , almost indifferent what port we made for , -- Hamburg , Rotterdam , Antwerp , -- the place signified little , so that he was out of England .
Parsing [sent. 8420 len. 16]: Any foreign steamer that fell in our way and would take us up would do .

Parsing [sent. 8423 len. 28]: The time when one would be due where we lay , wherever that might be , could be calculated pretty nearly , if we made inquiries beforehand .

Parsing [sent. 8426 len. 30]: But we noted down what other foreign steamers would leave London with the same tide , and we satisfied ourselves that we knew the build and color of each .

Parsing [sent. 8429 len. 25]: I , for my part , was prepared with passports ; Herbert had seen Startop , and he was more than ready to join .

Parsing [sent. 8431 len. 94]: We arranged that Herbert should not come home to dinner before going to Mill Pond Bank that evening ; that he should not go there at all to-morrow evening , Tuesday ; that he should prepare Provis to come down to some stairs hard by the house , on Wednesday , when he saw us approach , and not sooner ; that all the arrangements with him should be concluded that Monday night ; and that he should be communicated with no more in any way , until we took him on board .
Parsing [sent. 8432 len. 13]: These precautions well understood by both of us , I went home .

Parsing [sent. 8438 len. 16]: I had had load enough upon my mind before the receipt of this strange letter .
Parsing [sent. 8439 len. 10]: What to do now , I could not tell .

Parsing [sent. 8447 len. 46]: It is so difficult to become clearly possessed of the contents of almost any letter , in a violent hurry , that I had to read this mysterious epistle again twice , before its injunction to me to be secret got mechanically into my mind .
Parsing [sent. 8448 len. 58]: Yielding to it in the same mechanical kind of way , I left a note in pencil for Herbert , telling him that as I should be so soon going away , I knew not for how long , I had decided to hurry down and back , to ascertain for myself how Miss Havisham was faring .
Parsing [sent. 8449 len. 25]: I had then barely time to get my great-coat , lock up the chambers , and make for the coach-office by the short by-ways .
