Parsing [sent. 8452 len. 28]: For I really had not been myself since the receipt of the letter ; it had so bewildered me , ensuing on the hurry of the morning .
Parsing [sent. 8453 len. 31]: The morning hurry and flutter had been great ; for , long and anxiously as I had waited for Wemmick , his hint had come like a surprise at last .
Parsing [sent. 8454 len. 75]: And now I began to wonder at myself for being in the coach , and to doubt whether I had sufficient reason for being there , and to consider whether I should get out presently and go back , and to argue against ever heeding an anonymous communication , and , in short , to pass through all those phases of contradiction and indecision to which I suppose very few hurried people are strangers .
Parsing [sent. 8455 len. 11]: Still , the reference to Provis by name mastered everything .
Parsing [sent. 8456 len. 37]: I reasoned as I had reasoned already without knowing it , -- if that be reasoning , -- in case any harm should befall him through my not going , how could I ever forgive myself !
Parsing [sent. 8457 len. 37]: It was dark before we got down , and the journey seemed long and dreary to me , who could see little of it inside , and who could not go outside in my disabled state .
Parsing [sent. 8458 len. 23]: Avoiding the Blue Boar , I put up at an inn of minor reputation down the town , and ordered some dinner .
Parsing [sent. 8459 len. 27]: While it was preparing , I went to Satis House and inquired for Miss Havisham ; she was still very ill , though considered something better .
Parsing [sent. 8460 len. 26]: My inn had once been a part of an ancient ecclesiastical house , and I dined in a little octagonal common-room , like a font .
Parsing [sent. 8461 len. 23]: As I was not able to cut my dinner , the old landlord with a shining bald head did it for me .
Parsing [sent. 8462 len. 39]: This bringing us into conversation , he was so good as to entertain me with my own story , -- of course with the popular feature that Pumblechook was my earliest benefactor and the founder of my fortunes .
Parsing [sent. 8463 len. 9]: `` Do you know the young man ? ''
Parsing [sent. 8464 len. 7]: said I. `` Know him ! ''
Parsing [sent. 8465 len. 4]: repeated the landlord .
Parsing [sent. 8466 len. 12]: `` Ever since he was -- no height at all . ''
Parsing [sent. 8467 len. 11]: `` Does he ever come back to this neighborhood ? ''
Parsing [sent. 8468 len. 35]: `` Ay , he comes back , '' said the landlord , `` to his great friends , now and again , and gives the cold shoulder to the man that made him . ''
Parsing [sent. 8469 len. 7]: `` What man is that ? ''
Parsing [sent. 8470 len. 12]: `` Him that I speak of , '' said the landlord .
Parsing [sent. 8471 len. 5]: `` Mr. Pumblechook . ''
Parsing [sent. 8472 len. 10]: `` Is he ungrateful to no one else ? ''
Parsing [sent. 8473 len. 22]: `` No doubt he would be , if he could , '' returned the landlord , `` but he ca n't .
Parsing [sent. 8474 len. 3]: And why ?
Parsing [sent. 8475 len. 8]: Because Pumblechook done everything for him . ''
Parsing [sent. 8476 len. 7]: `` Does Pumblechook say so ? ''
Parsing [sent. 8477 len. 5]: `` Say so ! ''
Parsing [sent. 8478 len. 4]: replied the landlord .
Parsing [sent. 8479 len. 11]: `` He ha n't no call to say so . ''
Parsing [sent. 8480 len. 8]: `` But does he say so ? ''
Parsing [sent. 8481 len. 26]: `` It would turn a man 's blood to white wine winegar to hear him tell of it , sir , '' said the landlord .
Parsing [sent. 8482 len. 16]: I thought , `` Yet Joe , dear Joe , you never tell of it .
Parsing [sent. 8483 len. 9]: Long-suffering and loving Joe , you never complain .
Parsing [sent. 8484 len. 7]: Nor you , sweet-tempered Biddy ! ''
Parsing [sent. 8485 len. 25]: `` Your appetite 's been touched like by your accident , '' said the landlord , glancing at the bandaged arm under my coat .
Parsing [sent. 8486 len. 7]: `` Try a tenderer bit . ''
Parsing [sent. 8487 len. 20]: `` No , thank you , '' I replied , turning from the table to brood over the fire .
Parsing [sent. 8488 len. 7]: `` I can eat no more .
Parsing [sent. 8489 len. 6]: Please take it away . ''
Parsing [sent. 8490 len. 22]: I had never been struck at so keenly , for my thanklessness to Joe , as through the brazen impostor Pumblechook .
Parsing [sent. 8491 len. 16]: The falser he , the truer Joe ; the meaner he , the nobler Joe .
Parsing [sent. 8492 len. 20]: My heart was deeply and most deservedly humbled as I mused over the fire for an hour or more .
Parsing [sent. 8493 len. 33]: The striking of the clock aroused me , but not from my dejection or remorse , and I got up and had my coat fastened round my neck , and went out .
Parsing [sent. 8494 len. 44]: I had previously sought in my pockets for the letter , that I might refer to it again ; but I could not find it , and was uneasy to think that it must have been dropped in the straw of the coach .
Parsing [sent. 8495 len. 27]: I knew very well , however , that the appointed place was the little sluice-house by the limekiln on the marshes , and the hour nine .
Parsing [sent. 8496 len. 14]: Towards the marshes I now went straight , having no time to spare .
Parsing [sent. 8497 len. 27]: Chapter LIII It was a dark night , though the full moon rose as I left the enclosed lands , and passed out upon the marshes .
Parsing [sent. 8498 len. 22]: Beyond their dark line there was a ribbon of clear sky , hardly broad enough to hold the red large moon .
Parsing [sent. 8499 len. 21]: In a few minutes she had ascended out of that clear field , in among the piled mountains of cloud .
Parsing [sent. 8500 len. 13]: There was a melancholy wind , and the marshes were very dismal .
Parsing [sent. 8501 len. 26]: A stranger would have found them insupportable , and even to me they were so oppressive that I hesitated , half inclined to go back .
Parsing [sent. 8502 len. 28]: But I knew them well , and could have found my way on a far darker night , and had no excuse for returning , being there .
Parsing [sent. 8503 len. 15]: So , having come there against my inclination , I went on against it .
Parsing [sent. 8504 len. 25]: The direction that I took was not that in which my old home lay , nor that in which we had pursued the convicts .
Parsing [sent. 8505 len. 36]: My back was turned towards the distant Hulks as I walked on , and , though I could see the old lights away on the spits of sand , I saw them over my shoulder .
Parsing [sent. 8506 len. 51]: I knew the limekiln as well as I knew the old Battery , but they were miles apart ; so that , if a light had been burning at each point that night , there would have been a long strip of the blank horizon between the two bright specks .
Parsing [sent. 8507 len. 39]: At first , I had to shut some gates after me , and now and then to stand still while the cattle that were lying in the banked-up pathway arose and blundered down among the grass and reeds .
Parsing [sent. 8508 len. 15]: But after a little while I seemed to have the whole flats to myself .
Parsing [sent. 8509 len. 12]: It was another half-hour before I drew near to the kiln .
Parsing [sent. 8510 len. 25]: The lime was burning with a sluggish stifling smell , but the fires were made up and left , and no workmen were visible .
Parsing [sent. 8511 len. 7]: Hard by was a small stone-quarry .
Parsing [sent. 8512 len. 27]: It lay directly in my way , and had been worked that day , as I saw by the tools and barrows that were lying about .
Parsing [sent. 8513 len. 31]: Coming up again to the marsh level out of this excavation , -- for the rude path lay through it , -- I saw a light in the old sluice-house .
Parsing [sent. 8514 len. 14]: I quickened my pace , and knocked at the door with my hand .
Parsing [sent. 8515 len. 75]: Waiting for some reply , I looked about me , noticing how the sluice was abandoned and broken , and how the house -- of wood with a tiled roof -- would not be proof against the weather much longer , if it were so even now , and how the mud and ooze were coated with lime , and how the choking vapor of the kiln crept in a ghostly way towards me .
Parsing [sent. 8516 len. 11]: Still there was no answer , and I knocked again .
Parsing [sent. 8517 len. 10]: No answer still , and I tried the latch .
Parsing [sent. 8518 len. 11]: It rose under my hand , and the door yielded .
Parsing [sent. 8519 len. 23]: Looking in , I saw a lighted candle on a table , a bench , and a mattress on a truckle bedstead .
Parsing [sent. 8520 len. 18]: As there was a loft above , I called , `` Is there any one here ? ''
Parsing [sent. 8521 len. 5]: but no voice answered .
Parsing [sent. 8522 len. 27]: Then I looked at my watch , and , finding that it was past nine , called again , `` Is there any one here ? ''
Parsing [sent. 8523 len. 18]: There being still no answer , I went out at the door , irresolute what to do .
Parsing [sent. 8524 len. 7]: It was beginning to rain fast .
Parsing [sent. 8525 len. 32]: Seeing nothing save what I had seen already , I turned back into the house , and stood just within the shelter of the doorway , looking out into the night .
Parsing [sent. 8526 len. 40]: While I was considering that some one must have been there lately and must soon be coming back , or the candle would not be burning , it came into my head to look if the wick were long .
Parsing [sent. 8527 len. 52]: I turned round to do so , and had taken up the candle in my hand , when it was extinguished by some violent shock ; and the next thing I comprehended was , that I had been caught in a strong running noose , thrown over my head from behind .
Parsing [sent. 8528 len. 19]: `` Now , '' said a suppressed voice with an oath , `` I 've got you ! ''
Parsing [sent. 8529 len. 6]: `` What is this ? ''
Parsing [sent. 8530 len. 5]: I cried , struggling .
Parsing [sent. 8531 len. 5]: `` Who is it ?
Parsing [sent. 8532 len. 7]: Help , help , help ! ''
Parsing [sent. 8533 len. 23]: Not only were my arms pulled close to my sides , but the pressure on my bad arm caused me exquisite pain .
Parsing [sent. 8534 len. 51]: Sometimes , a strong man 's hand , sometimes a strong man 's breast , was set against my mouth to deaden my cries , and with a hot breath always close to me , I struggled ineffectually in the dark , while I was fastened tight to the wall .
Parsing [sent. 8535 len. 28]: `` And now , '' said the suppressed voice with another oath , `` call out again , and I 'll make short work of you ! ''
Parsing [sent. 8536 len. 44]: Faint and sick with the pain of my injured arm , bewildered by the surprise , and yet conscious how easily this threat could be put in execution , I desisted , and tried to ease my arm were it ever so little .
Parsing [sent. 8537 len. 10]: But , it was bound too tight for that .
Parsing [sent. 8538 len. 16]: I felt as if , having been burnt before , it were now being boiled .
Parsing [sent. 8539 len. 27]: The sudden exclusion of the night , and the substitution of black darkness in its place , warned me that the man had closed a shutter .
Parsing [sent. 8540 len. 23]: After groping about for a little , he found the flint and steel he wanted , and began to strike a light .
Parsing [sent. 8541 len. 46]: I strained my sight upon the sparks that fell among the tinder , and upon which he breathed and breathed , match in hand , but I could only see his lips , and the blue point of the match ; even those but fitfully .
Parsing [sent. 8542 len. 20]: The tinder was damp , -- no wonder there , -- and one after another the sparks died out .
Parsing [sent. 8543 len. 16]: The man was in no hurry , and struck again with the flint and steel .
Parsing [sent. 8544 len. 40]: As the sparks fell thick and bright about him , I could see his hands , and touches of his face , and could make out that he was seated and bending over the table ; but nothing more .
Parsing [sent. 8545 len. 27]: Presently I saw his blue lips again , breathing on the tinder , and then a flare of light flashed up , and showed me Orlick .
Parsing [sent. 8546 len. 11]: Whom I had looked for , I do n't know .
Parsing [sent. 8547 len. 7]: I had not looked for him .
Parsing [sent. 8548 len. 22]: Seeing him , I felt that I was in a dangerous strait indeed , and I kept my eyes upon him .
Parsing [sent. 8549 len. 22]: He lighted the candle from the flaring match with great deliberation , and dropped the match , and trod it out .
Parsing [sent. 8550 len. 33]: Then he put the candle away from him on the table , so that he could see me , and sat with his arms folded on the table and looked at me .
Parsing [sent. 8551 len. 34]: I made out that I was fastened to a stout perpendicular ladder a few inches from the wall , -- a fixture there , -- the means of ascent to the loft above .
Parsing [sent. 8552 len. 24]: `` Now , '' said he , when we had surveyed one another for some time , `` I 've got you . ''
Parsing [sent. 8553 len. 4]: `` Unbind me .
Parsing [sent. 8554 len. 5]: Let me go ! ''
Parsing [sent. 8555 len. 4]: `` Ah ! ''
Parsing [sent. 8556 len. 10]: he returned , `` I 'll let you go .
Parsing [sent. 8557 len. 18]: I 'll let you go to the moon , I 'll let you go to the stars .
Parsing [sent. 8558 len. 6]: All in good time . ''
Parsing [sent. 8559 len. 9]: `` Why have you lured me here ? ''
Parsing [sent. 8560 len. 7]: `` Do n't you know ? ''
Parsing [sent. 8561 len. 8]: said he , with a deadly look .
Parsing [sent. 8562 len. 12]: `` Why have you set upon me in the dark ? ''
Parsing [sent. 8563 len. 10]: `` Because I mean to do it all myself .
Parsing [sent. 8564 len. 8]: One keeps a secret better than two .
Parsing [sent. 8565 len. 8]: O you enemy , you enemy ! ''
Parsing [sent. 8566 len. 38]: His enjoyment of the spectacle I furnished , as he sat with his arms folded on the table , shaking his head at me and hugging himself , had a malignity in it that made me tremble .
Parsing [sent. 8567 len. 28]: As I watched him in silence , he put his hand into the corner at his side , and took up a gun with a brass-bound stock .
Parsing [sent. 8568 len. 7]: `` Do you know this ? ''
Parsing [sent. 8569 len. 13]: said he , making as if he would take aim at me .
Parsing [sent. 8570 len. 10]: `` Do you know where you saw it afore ?
Parsing [sent. 8571 len. 5]: Speak , wolf ! ''
Parsing [sent. 8572 len. 7]: `` Yes , '' I answered .
Parsing [sent. 8573 len. 7]: `` You cost me that place .
Parsing [sent. 8574 len. 3]: You did .
Parsing [sent. 8575 len. 3]: Speak ! ''
Parsing [sent. 8576 len. 8]: `` What else could I do ? ''
Parsing [sent. 8577 len. 14]: `` You did that , and that would be enough , without more .
Parsing [sent. 8578 len. 15]: How dared you to come betwixt me and a young woman I liked ? ''
Parsing [sent. 8579 len. 6]: `` When did I ? ''
Parsing [sent. 8580 len. 6]: `` When did n't you ?
Parsing [sent. 8581 len. 15]: It was you as always give Old Orlick a bad name to her . ''
Parsing [sent. 8582 len. 13]: `` You gave it to yourself ; you gained it for yourself .
Parsing [sent. 8583 len. 16]: I could have done you no harm , if you had done yourself none . ''
Parsing [sent. 8584 len. 6]: `` You 're a liar .
Parsing [sent. 8585 len. 24]: And you 'll take any pains , and spend any money , to drive me out of this country , will you ? ''
Parsing [sent. 8586 len. 17]: said he , repeating my words to Biddy in the last interview I had with her .
Parsing [sent. 8587 len. 12]: `` Now , I 'll tell you a piece of information .
Parsing [sent. 8588 len. 20]: It was never so well worth your while to get me out of this country as it is to-night .
Parsing [sent. 8589 len. 2]: Ah !
Parsing [sent. 8590 len. 17]: If it was all your money twenty times told , to the last brass farden ! ''
Parsing [sent. 8591 len. 25]: As he shook his heavy hand at me , with his mouth snarling like a tiger 's , I felt that it was true .
Parsing [sent. 8592 len. 11]: `` What are you going to do to me ? ''
Parsing [sent. 8593 len. 46]: `` I 'm a going , '' said he , bringing his fist down upon the table with a heavy blow , and rising as the blow fell to give it greater force , -- `` I 'm a going to have your life ! ''
Parsing [sent. 8594 len. 30]: He leaned forward staring at me , slowly unclenched his hand and drew it across his mouth as if his mouth watered for me , and sat down again .

Parsing [sent. 8596 len. 10]: You goes out of his way this present night .
Parsing [sent. 8597 len. 8]: He 'll have no more on you .
Parsing [sent. 8598 len. 5]: You 're dead . ''
Parsing [sent. 8599 len. 13]: I felt that I had come to the brink of my grave .
Parsing [sent. 8600 len. 20]: For a moment I looked wildly round my trap for any chance of escape ; but there was none .
Parsing [sent. 8601 len. 40]: `` More than that , '' said he , folding his arms on the table again , `` I wo n't have a rag of you , I wo n't have a bone of you , left on earth .
Parsing [sent. 8602 len. 41]: I 'll put your body in the kiln , -- I 'd carry two such to it , on my Shoulders , -- and , let people suppose what they may of you , they shall never know nothing . ''
Parsing [sent. 8603 len. 16]: My mind , with inconceivable rapidity followed out all the consequences of such a death .
Parsing [sent. 8604 len. 91]: Estella 's father would believe I had deserted him , would be taken , would die accusing me ; even Herbert would doubt me , when he compared the letter I had left for him with the fact that I had called at Miss Havisham 's gate for only a moment ; Joe and Biddy would never know how sorry I had been that night , none would ever know what I had suffered , how true I had meant to be , what an agony I had passed through .
Parsing [sent. 8605 len. 23]: The death close before me was terrible , but far more terrible than death was the dread of being misremembered after death .
Parsing [sent. 8606 len. 37]: And so quick were my thoughts , that I saw myself despised by unborn generations , -- Estella 's children , and their children , -- while the wretch 's words were yet on his lips .
Parsing [sent. 8607 len. 52]: `` Now , wolf , '' said he , `` afore I kill you like any other beast , -- which is wot I mean to do and wot I have tied you up for , -- I 'll have a good look at you and a good goad at you .
Parsing [sent. 8608 len. 5]: O you enemy ! ''
Parsing [sent. 8609 len. 34]: It had passed through my thoughts to cry out for help again ; though few could know better than I , the solitary nature of the spot , and the hopelessness of aid .
Parsing [sent. 8610 len. 22]: But as he sat gloating over me , I was supported by a scornful detestation of him that sealed my lips .
Parsing [sent. 8611 len. 26]: Above all things , I resolved that I would not entreat him , and that I would die making some last poor resistance to him .
Parsing [sent. 8612 len. 96]: Softened as my thoughts of all the rest of men were in that dire extremity ; humbly beseeching pardon , as I did , of Heaven ; melted at heart , as I was , by the thought that I had taken no farewell , and never now could take farewell of those who were dear to me , or could explain myself to them , or ask for their compassion on my miserable errors , -- still , if I could have killed him , even in dying , I would have done it .
Parsing [sent. 8613 len. 13]: He had been drinking , and his eyes were red and bloodshot .
Parsing [sent. 8614 len. 25]: Around his neck was slung a tin bottle , as I had often seen his meat and drink slung about him in other days .
Parsing [sent. 8615 len. 30]: He brought the bottle to his lips , and took a fiery drink from it ; and I smelt the strong spirits that I saw flash into his face .
Parsing [sent. 8616 len. 4]: `` Wolf ! ''
Parsing [sent. 8617 len. 19]: said he , folding his arms again , `` Old Orlick 's a going to tell you somethink .
Parsing [sent. 8618 len. 11]: It was you as did for your shrew sister . ''
Parsing [sent. 8619 len. 40]: Again my mind , with its former inconceivable rapidity , had exhausted the whole subject of the attack upon my sister , her illness , and her death , before his slow and hesitating speech had formed these words .
Parsing [sent. 8620 len. 52]: `` It was you , villain , '' said I. `` I tell you it was your doing , -- I tell you it was done through you , '' he retorted , catching up the gun , and making a blow with the stock at the vacant air between us .
Parsing [sent. 8621 len. 15]: `` I come upon her from behind , as I come upon you to-night .
Parsing [sent. 8622 len. 6]: I giv ' it her !
Parsing [sent. 8623 len. 32]: I left her for dead , and if there had been a limekiln as nigh her as there is now nigh you , she should n't have come to life again .
Parsing [sent. 8624 len. 14]: But it war n't Old Orlick as did it ; it was you .
Parsing [sent. 8625 len. 11]: You was favored , and he was bullied and beat .
Parsing [sent. 8626 len. 8]: Old Orlick bullied and beat , eh ?
Parsing [sent. 8627 len. 6]: Now you pays for it .
Parsing [sent. 8628 len. 11]: You done it ; now you pays for it . ''
Parsing [sent. 8629 len. 9]: He drank again , and became more ferocious .
Parsing [sent. 8630 len. 18]: I saw by his tilting of the bottle that there was no great quantity left in it .
Parsing [sent. 8631 len. 19]: I distinctly understood that he was working himself up with its contents to make an end of me .
Parsing [sent. 8632 len. 14]: I knew that every drop it held was a drop of my life .
Parsing [sent. 8633 len. 62]: I knew that when I was changed into a part of the vapor that had crept towards me but a little while before , like my own warning ghost , he would do as he had done in my sister 's case , -- make all haste to the town , and be seen slouching about there drinking at the alehouses .
Parsing [sent. 8634 len. 45]: My rapid mind pursued him to the town , made a picture of the street with him in it , and contrasted its lights and life with the lonely marsh and the white vapor creeping over it , into which I should have dissolved .
Parsing [sent. 8635 len. 38]: It was not only that I could have summed up years and years and years while he said a dozen words , but that what he did say presented pictures to me , and not mere words .
Parsing [sent. 8636 len. 28]: In the excited and exalted state of my brain , I could not think of a place without seeing it , or of persons without seeing them .
Parsing [sent. 8637 len. 39]: It is impossible to overstate the vividness of these images , and yet I was so intent , all the time , upon him himself , -- who would not be intent on the tiger crouching to spring !
Parsing [sent. 8638 len. 12]: -- that I knew of the slightest action of his fingers .
Parsing [sent. 8639 len. 24]: When he had drunk this second time , he rose from the bench on which he sat , and pushed the table aside .
Parsing [sent. 8640 len. 37]: Then , he took up the candle , and , shading it with his murderous hand so as to throw its light on me , stood before me , looking at me and enjoying the sight .
Parsing [sent. 8641 len. 10]: `` Wolf , I 'll tell you something more .
Parsing [sent. 8642 len. 15]: It was Old Orlick as you tumbled over on your stairs that night . ''
Parsing [sent. 8643 len. 9]: I saw the staircase with its extinguished lamps .
Parsing [sent. 8644 len. 19]: I saw the shadows of the heavy stair-rails , thrown by the watchman 's lantern on the wall .
Parsing [sent. 8645 len. 32]: I saw the rooms that I was never to see again ; here , a door half open ; there , a door closed ; all the articles of furniture around .
Parsing [sent. 8646 len. 8]: `` And why was Old Orlick there ?
Parsing [sent. 8647 len. 9]: I 'll tell you something more , wolf .
Parsing [sent. 8648 len. 37]: You and her have pretty well hunted me out of this country , so far as getting a easy living in it goes , and I 've took up with new companions , and new masters .
Parsing [sent. 8649 len. 17]: Some of 'em writes my letters when I wants 'em wrote , -- do you mind ?
Parsing [sent. 8650 len. 7]: -- writes my letters , wolf !
Parsing [sent. 8651 len. 17]: They writes fifty hands ; they 're not like sneaking you , as writes but one .
Parsing [sent. 8652 len. 26]: I 've had a firm mind and a firm will to have your life , since you was down here at your sister 's burying .
Parsing [sent. 8653 len. 24]: I ha n't seen a way to get you safe , and I 've looked arter you to know your ins and outs .

Parsing [sent. 8656 len. 15]: When I looks for you , I finds your uncle Provis , eh ? ''
Parsing [sent. 8657 len. 22]: Mill Pond Bank , and Chinks 's Basin , and the Old Green Copper Ropewalk , all so clear and plain !
Parsing [sent. 8658 len. 45]: Provis in his rooms , the signal whose use was over , pretty Clara , the good motherly woman , old Bill Barley on his back , all drifting by , as on the swift stream of my life fast running out to sea !
Parsing [sent. 8659 len. 7]: `` You with a uncle too !
Parsing [sent. 8660 len. 67]: Why , I know 'd you at Gargery 's when you was so small a wolf that I could have took your weazen betwixt this finger and thumb and chucked you away dead -LRB- as I 'd thoughts o ' doing , odd times , when I see you loitering amongst the pollards on a Sunday -RRB- , and you had n't found no uncles then .
Parsing [sent. 8661 len. 5]: No , not you !
Parsing [sent. 8662 len. 64]: But when Old Orlick come for to hear that your uncle Provis had most like wore the leg-iron wot Old Orlick had picked up , filed asunder , on these meshes ever so many year ago , and wot he kep by him till he dropped your sister with it , like a bullock , as he means to drop you -- hey ?
Parsing [sent. 8663 len. 12]: -- when he come for to hear that -- hey ? ''
Parsing [sent. 8664 len. 26]: In his savage taunting , he flared the candle so close at me that I turned my face aside to save it from the flame .
Parsing [sent. 8665 len. 4]: `` Ah ! ''
Parsing [sent. 8666 len. 18]: he cried , laughing , after doing it again , `` the burnt child dreads the fire !

Parsing [sent. 8668 len. 15]: Now I 'll tell you something more , wolf , and this ends it .
Parsing [sent. 8669 len. 21]: There 's them that 's as good a match for your uncle Provis as Old Orlick has been for you .
Parsing [sent. 8670 len. 13]: Let him ` ware them , when he 's lost his nevvy !

Parsing [sent. 8675 len. 11]: ` Ware Compeyson , Magwitch , and the gallows ! ''
Parsing [sent. 8676 len. 35]: He flared the candle at me again , smoking my face and hair , and for an instant blinding me , and turned his powerful back as he replaced the light on the table .
Parsing [sent. 8677 len. 23]: I had thought a prayer , and had been with Joe and Biddy and Herbert , before he turned towards me again .
Parsing [sent. 8678 len. 17]: There was a clear space of a few feet between the table and the opposite wall .
Parsing [sent. 8679 len. 11]: Within this space , he now slouched backwards and forwards .
Parsing [sent. 8680 len. 36]: His great strength seemed to sit stronger upon him than ever before , as he did this with his hands hanging loose and heavy at his sides , and with his eyes scowling at me .
Parsing [sent. 8681 len. 8]: I had no grain of hope left .
Parsing [sent. 8682 len. 60]: Wild as my inward hurry was , and wonderful the force of the pictures that rushed by me instead of thoughts , I could yet clearly understand that , unless he had resolved that I was within a few moments of surely perishing out of all human knowledge , he would never have told me what he had told .
Parsing [sent. 8683 len. 20]: Of a sudden , he stopped , took the cork out of his bottle , and tossed it away .
Parsing [sent. 8684 len. 13]: Light as it was , I heard it fall like a plummet .
Parsing [sent. 8685 len. 22]: He swallowed slowly , tilting up the bottle by little and little , and now he looked at me no more .
Parsing [sent. 8686 len. 19]: The last few drops of liquor he poured into the palm of his hand , and licked up .
Parsing [sent. 8687 len. 36]: Then , with a sudden hurry of violence and swearing horribly , he threw the bottle from him , and stooped ; and I saw in his hand a stone-hammer with a long heavy handle .
Parsing [sent. 8688 len. 37]: The resolution I had made did not desert me , for , without uttering one vain word of appeal to him , I shouted out with all my might , and struggled with all my might .
Parsing [sent. 8689 len. 33]: It was only my head and my legs that I could move , but to that extent I struggled with all the force , until then unknown , that was within me .
Parsing [sent. 8690 len. 58]: In the same instant I heard responsive shouts , saw figures and a gleam of light dash in at the door , heard voices and tumult , and saw Orlick emerge from a struggle of men , as if it were tumbling water , clear the table at a leap , and fly out into the night .
Parsing [sent. 8691 len. 30]: After a blank , I found that I was lying unbound , on the floor , in the same place , with my head on some one 's knee .
Parsing [sent. 8692 len. 50]: My eyes were fixed on the ladder against the wall , when I came to myself , -- had opened on it before my mind saw it , -- and thus as I recovered consciousness , I knew that I was in the place where I had lost it .
Parsing [sent. 8693 len. 33]: Too indifferent at first , even to look round and ascertain who supported me , I was lying looking at the ladder , when there came between me and it a face .

Parsing [sent. 8726 len. 84]: Entreating Herbert to tell me how he had come to my rescue , -- which at first he had flatly refused to do , but had insisted on my remaining quiet , -- I learnt that I had in my hurry dropped the letter , open , in our chambers , where he , coming home to bring with him Startop whom he had met in the street on his way to me , found it , very soon after I was gone .

Parsing [sent. 8728 len. 40]: His uneasiness increasing instead of subsiding , after a quarter of an hour 's consideration , he set off for the coach-office with Startop , who volunteered his company , to make inquiry when the next coach went down .
Parsing [sent. 8729 len. 33]: Finding that the afternoon coach was gone , and finding that his uneasiness grew into positive alarm , as obstacles came in his way , he resolved to follow in a post-chaise .
Parsing [sent. 8730 len. 39]: So he and Startop arrived at the Blue Boar , fully expecting there to find me , or tidings of me ; but , finding neither , went on to Miss Havisham 's , where they lost me .

Parsing [sent. 8732 len. 52]: Among the loungers under the Boar 's archway happened to be Trabb 's Boy , -- true to his ancient habit of happening to be everywhere where he had no business , -- and Trabb 's boy had seen me passing from Miss Havisham 's in the direction of my dining-place .

Parsing [sent. 8734 len. 83]: Now , as they went along , Herbert reflected , that I might , after all , have been brought there on some genuine and serviceable errand tending to Provis 's safety , and , bethinking himself that in that case interruption must be mischievous , left his guide and Startop on the edge of the quarry , and went on by himself , and stole round the house two or three times , endeavouring to ascertain whether all was right within .

Parsing [sent. 8744 len. 24]: It was daylight when we reached the Temple , and I went at once to bed , and lay in bed all day .
Parsing [sent. 8745 len. 33]: My terror , as I lay there , of falling ill , and being unfitted for tomorrow , was so besetting , that I wonder it did not disable me of itself .

Parsing [sent. 8751 len. 36]: As the days wore on , and no ill news came , as the day closed in and darkness fell , my overshadowing dread of being disabled by illness before to-morrow morning altogether mastered me .
Parsing [sent. 8752 len. 20]: My burning arm throbbed , and my burning head throbbed , and I fancied I was beginning to wander .

Parsing [sent. 8754 len. 44]: It happened sometimes that in the mere escape of a fatigued mind , I dozed for some moments or forgot ; then I would say to myself with a start , `` Now it has come , and I am turning delirious ! ''

Parsing [sent. 8768 len. 34]: Chapter LIV It was one of those March days when the sun shines hot and the wind blows cold : when it is summer in the light , and winter in the shade .
Parsing [sent. 8769 len. 13]: We had out pea-coats with us , and I took a bag .

Parsing [sent. 8774 len. 18]: Of course , I had taken care that the boat should be ready and everything in order .

Parsing [sent. 8776 len. 10]: It was then about high-water , -- half-past eight .
Parsing [sent. 8777 len. 5]: Our plan was this .
Parsing [sent. 8778 len. 35]: The tide , beginning to run down at nine , and being with us until three , we intended still to creep on after it had turned , and row against it until dark .
Parsing [sent. 8779 len. 53]: We should then be well in those long reaches below Gravesend , between Kent and Essex , where the river is broad and solitary , where the water-side inhabitants are very few , and where lone public-houses are scattered here and there , of which we could choose one for a resting-place .
Parsing [sent. 8780 len. 10]: There , we meant to lie by all night .
Parsing [sent. 8781 len. 20]: The steamer for Hamburg and the steamer for Rotterdam would start from London at about nine on Thursday morning .
Parsing [sent. 8782 len. 41]: We should know at what time to expect them , according to where we were , and would hail the first ; so that , if by any accident we were not taken abroad , we should have another chance .
Parsing [sent. 8783 len. 9]: We knew the distinguishing marks of each vessel .
Parsing [sent. 8784 len. 37]: The relief of being at last engaged in the execution of the purpose was so great to me that I felt it difficult to realize the condition in which I had been a few hours before .
Parsing [sent. 8785 len. 48]: The crisp air , the sunlight , the movement on the river , and the moving river itself , -- the road that ran with us , seeming to sympathize with us , animate us , and encourage us on , -- freshened me with new hope .
Parsing [sent. 8786 len. 39]: I felt mortified to be of so little use in the boat ; but , there were few better oarsmen than my two friends , and they rowed with a steady stroke that was to last all day .
Parsing [sent. 8787 len. 25]: At that time , the steam-traffic on the Thames was far below its present extent , and watermen 's boats were far more numerous .
Parsing [sent. 8788 len. 36]: Of barges , sailing colliers , and coasting-traders , there were perhaps , as many as now ; but of steam-ships , great and small , not a tithe or a twentieth part so many .
Parsing [sent. 8789 len. 67]: Early as it was , there were plenty of scullers going here and there that morning , and plenty of barges dropping down with the tide ; the navigation of the river between bridges , in an open boat , was a much easier and commoner matter in those days than it is in these ; and we went ahead among many skiffs and wherries briskly .
Parsing [sent. 8790 len. 36]: Old London Bridge was soon passed , and old Billingsgate Market with its oyster-boats and Dutchmen , and the White Tower and Traitor 's Gate , and we were in among the tiers of shipping .
Parsing [sent. 8791 len. 99]: Here were the Leith , Aberdeen , and Glasgow steamers , loading and unloading goods , and looking immensely high out of the water as we passed alongside ; here , were colliers by the score and score , with the coal-whippers plunging off stages on deck , as counterweights to measures of coal swinging up , which were then rattled over the side into barges ; here , at her moorings was to-morrow 's steamer for Rotterdam , of which we took good notice ; and here to-morrow 's for Hamburg , under whose bowsprit we crossed .

Parsing [sent. 8810 len. 191]: Again among the tiers of shipping , in and out , avoiding rusty chain-cables frayed hempen hawsers and bobbing buoys , sinking for the moment floating broken baskets , scattering floating chips of wood and shaving , cleaving floating scum of coal , in and out , under the figure-head of the John of Sunderland making a speech to the winds -LRB- as is done by many Johns -RRB- , and the Betsy of Yarmouth with a firm formality of bosom and her knobby eyes starting two inches out of her head ; in and out , hammers going in ship-builders ' yards , saws going at timber , clashing engines going at things unknown , pumps going in leaky ships , capstans going , ships going out to sea , and unintelligible sea-creatures roaring curses over the bulwarks at respondent lightermen , in and out , -- out at last upon the clearer river , where the ships ' boys might take their fenders in , no longer fishing in troubled waters with them over the side , and where the festooned sails might fly out to the wind .

Parsing [sent. 8847 len. 22]: The air felt cold upon the river , but it was a bright day , and the sunshine was very cheering .
Parsing [sent. 8848 len. 24]: The tide ran strong , I took care to lose none of it , and our steady stroke carried us on thoroughly well .
Parsing [sent. 8849 len. 45]: By imperceptible degrees , as the tide ran out , we lost more and more of the nearer woods and hills , and dropped lower and lower between the muddy banks , but the tide was yet with us when we were off Gravesend .
Parsing [sent. 8850 len. 57]: As our charge was wrapped in his cloak , I purposely passed within a boat or two 's length of the floating Custom House , and so out to catch the stream , alongside of two emigrant ships , and under the bows of a large transport with troops on the forecastle looking down at us .
Parsing [sent. 8851 len. 81]: And soon the tide began to slacken , and the craft lying at anchor to swing , and presently they had all swung round , and the ships that were taking advantage of the new tide to get up to the Pool began to crowd upon us in a fleet , and we kept under the shore , as much out of the strength of the tide now as we could , standing carefully off from low shallows and mudbanks .
Parsing [sent. 8852 len. 39]: Our oarsmen were so fresh , by dint of having occasionally let her drive with the tide for a minute or two , that a quarter of an hour 's rest proved full as much as they wanted .
Parsing [sent. 8853 len. 22]: We got ashore among some slippery stones while we ate and drank what we had with us , and looked about .
Parsing [sent. 8854 len. 45]: It was like my own marsh country , flat and monotonous , and with a dim horizon ; while the winding river turned and turned , and the great floating buoys upon it turned and turned , and everything else seemed stranded and still .
Parsing [sent. 8855 len. 127]: For now the last of the fleet of ships was round the last low point we had headed ; and the last green barge , straw-laden , with a brown sail , had followed ; and some ballast-lighters , shaped like a child 's first rude imitation of a boat , lay low in the mud ; and a little squat shoal-lighthouse on open piles stood crippled in the mud on stilts and crutches ; and slimy stakes stuck out of the mud , and slimy stones stuck out of the mud , and red landmarks and tidemarks stuck out of the mud , and an old landing-stage and an old roofless building slipped into the mud , and all about us was stagnation and mud .
Parsing [sent. 8856 len. 12]: We pushed off again , and made what way we could .
Parsing [sent. 8857 len. 25]: It was much harder work now , but Herbert and Startop persevered , and rowed and rowed and rowed until the sun went down .
Parsing [sent. 8858 len. 20]: By that time the river had lifted us a little , so that we could see above the bank .
Parsing [sent. 8859 len. 63]: There was the red sun , on the low level of the shore , in a purple haze , fast deepening into black ; and there was the solitary flat marsh ; and far away there were the rising grounds , between which and us there seemed to be no life , save here and there in the foreground a melancholy gull .
Parsing [sent. 8860 len. 49]: As the night was fast falling , and as the moon , being past the full , would not rise early , we held a little council ; a short one , for clearly our course was to lie by at the first lonely tavern we could find .
Parsing [sent. 8861 len. 19]: So , they plied their oars once more , and I looked out for anything like a house .
Parsing [sent. 8862 len. 15]: Thus we held on , speaking little , for four or five dull miles .
Parsing [sent. 8863 len. 26]: It was very cold , and , a collier coming by us , with her galley-fire smoking and flaring , looked like a comfortable home .
Parsing [sent. 8864 len. 45]: The night was as dark by this time as it would be until morning ; and what light we had , seemed to come more from the river than the sky , as the oars in their dipping struck at a few reflected stars .
Parsing [sent. 8865 len. 17]: At this dismal time we were evidently all possessed by the idea that we were followed .
Parsing [sent. 8866 len. 38]: As the tide made , it flapped heavily at irregular intervals against the shore ; and whenever such a sound came , one or other of us was sure to start , and look in that direction .
Parsing [sent. 8867 len. 33]: Here and there , the set of the current had worn down the bank into a little creek , and we were all suspicious of such places , and eyed them nervously .
Parsing [sent. 8868 len. 9]: Sometimes , `` What was that ripple ? ''
Parsing [sent. 8869 len. 10]: one of us would say in a low voice .
Parsing [sent. 8870 len. 11]: Or another , `` Is that a boat yonder ? ''
Parsing [sent. 8871 len. 30]: And afterwards we would fall into a dead silence , and I would sit impatiently thinking with what an unusual amount of noise the oars worked in the thowels .
Parsing [sent. 8872 len. 29]: At length we descried a light and a roof , and presently afterwards ran alongside a little causeway made of stones that had been picked up hard by .
Parsing [sent. 8873 len. 24]: Leaving the rest in the boat , I stepped ashore , and found the light to be in a window of a public-house .
Parsing [sent. 8874 len. 42]: It was a dirty place enough , and I dare say not unknown to smuggling adventurers ; but there was a good fire in the kitchen , and there were eggs and bacon to eat , and various liquors to drink .
Parsing [sent. 8875 len. 20]: Also , there were two double-bedded rooms , -- `` such as they were , '' the landlord said .
Parsing [sent. 8876 len. 44]: No other company was in the house than the landlord , his wife , and a grizzled male creature , the `` Jack '' of the little causeway , who was as slimy and smeary as if he had been low-water mark too .
Parsing [sent. 8877 len. 41]: With this assistant , I went down to the boat again , and we all came ashore , and brought out the oars , and rudder and boat-hook , and all else , and hauled her up for the night .
Parsing [sent. 8878 len. 32]: We made a very good meal by the kitchen fire , and then apportioned the bedrooms : Herbert and Startop were to occupy one ; I and our charge the other .
Parsing [sent. 8879 len. 38]: We found the air as carefully excluded from both , as if air were fatal to life ; and there were more dirty clothes and bandboxes under the beds than I should have thought the family possessed .
Parsing [sent. 8880 len. 20]: But we considered ourselves well off , notwithstanding , for a more solitary place we could not have found .
Parsing [sent. 8881 len. 81]: While we were comforting ourselves by the fire after our meal , the Jack -- who was sitting in a corner , and who had a bloated pair of shoes on , which he had exhibited while we were eating our eggs and bacon , as interesting relics that he had taken a few days ago from the feet of a drowned seaman washed ashore -- asked me if we had seen a four-oared galley going up with the tide ?
Parsing [sent. 8882 len. 29]: When I told him No , he said she must have gone down then , and yet she `` took up too , '' when she left there .
Parsing [sent. 8883 len. 26]: `` They must ha ' thought better o n't for some reason or another , '' said the Jack , `` and gone down . ''
Parsing [sent. 8884 len. 10]: `` A four-oared galley , did you say ? ''
Parsing [sent. 8885 len. 17]: said I. `` A four , '' said the Jack , `` and two sitters . ''
Parsing [sent. 8886 len. 8]: `` Did they come ashore here ? ''
Parsing [sent. 8887 len. 13]: `` They put in with a stone two-gallon jar for some beer .
Parsing [sent. 8888 len. 27]: I 'd ha ' been glad to pison the beer myself , '' said the Jack , `` or put some rattling physic in it . ''
Parsing [sent. 8889 len. 4]: `` Why ? ''
Parsing [sent. 8890 len. 10]: `` I know why , '' said the Jack .
Parsing [sent. 8891 len. 17]: He spoke in a slushy voice , as if much mud had washed into his throat .
Parsing [sent. 8892 len. 40]: `` He thinks , '' said the landlord , a weakly meditative man with a pale eye , who seemed to rely greatly on his Jack , -- `` he thinks they was , what they was n't . ''
Parsing [sent. 8893 len. 12]: `` I knows what I thinks , '' observed the Jack .
Parsing [sent. 8894 len. 10]: `` You thinks Custum ` Us , Jack ? ''
Parsing [sent. 8895 len. 4]: said the landlord .
Parsing [sent. 8896 len. 9]: `` I do , '' said the Jack .
Parsing [sent. 8897 len. 9]: `` Then you 're wrong , Jack . ''
Parsing [sent. 8898 len. 5]: `` AM I ! ''
Parsing [sent. 8899 len. 47]: In the infinite meaning of his reply and his boundless confidence in his views , the Jack took one of his bloated shoes off , looked into it , knocked a few stones out of it on the kitchen floor , and put it on again .
Parsing [sent. 8900 len. 21]: He did this with the air of a Jack who was so right that he could afford to do anything .
Parsing [sent. 8901 len. 19]: `` Why , what do you make out that they done with their buttons then , Jack ? ''
Parsing [sent. 8902 len. 7]: asked the landlord , vacillating weakly .
Parsing [sent. 8903 len. 7]: `` Done with their buttons ? ''
Parsing [sent. 8904 len. 4]: returned the Jack .

Parsing [sent. 8906 len. 3]: Swallered 'em .
Parsing [sent. 8907 len. 9]: Sowed 'em , to come up small salad .
Parsing [sent. 8908 len. 6]: Done with their buttons ! ''
Parsing [sent. 8909 len. 20]: `` Do n't be cheeky , Jack , '' remonstrated the landlord , in a melancholy and pathetic way .

Parsing [sent. 8911 len. 41]: A four and two sitters do n't go hanging and hovering , up with one tide and down with another , and both with and against another , without there being Custum ` Us at the bottom of it . ''
Parsing [sent. 8912 len. 27]: Saying which he went out in disdain ; and the landlord , having no one to reply upon , found it impracticable to pursue the subject .
Parsing [sent. 8913 len. 12]: This dialogue made us all uneasy , and me very uneasy .
Parsing [sent. 8914 len. 29]: The dismal wind was muttering round the house , the tide was flapping at the shore , and I had a feeling that we were caged and threatened .
Parsing [sent. 8915 len. 27]: A four-oared galley hovering about in so unusual a way as to attract this notice was an ugly circumstance that I could not get rid of .

Parsing [sent. 8918 len. 43]: On the whole we deemed it the better course to lie where we were , until within an hour or so of the steamer 's time , and then to get out in her track , and drift easily with the tide .
Parsing [sent. 8919 len. 16]: Having settled to do this , we returned into the house and went to bed .

Parsing [sent. 9064 len. 19]: `` Not so long as that , '' said I. `` Two or three months at most . ''

Parsing [sent. 9066 len. 5]: `` And Clara ? ''
Parsing [sent. 9067 len. 31]: said I. `` The dear little thing , '' returned Herbert , `` holds dutifully to her father as long as he lasts ; but he wo n't last long .

Parsing [sent. 9069 len. 22]: `` Not to say an unfeeling thing , '' said I , `` he can not do better than go . ''

Parsing [sent. 9169 len. 26]: Chapter LVI He lay in prison very ill , during the whole interval between his committal for trial and the coming round of the Sessions .
Parsing [sent. 9170 len. 27]: He had broken two ribs , they had wounded one of his lungs , and he breathed with great pain and difficulty , which increased daily .
Parsing [sent. 9171 len. 24]: It was a consequence of his hurt that he spoke so low as to be scarcely audible ; therefore he spoke very little .
Parsing [sent. 9172 len. 37]: But he was ever ready to listen to me ; and it became the first duty of my life to say to him , and read to him , what I knew he ought to hear .
Parsing [sent. 9173 len. 26]: Being far too ill to remain in the common prison , he was removed , after the first day or so , into the infirmary .
Parsing [sent. 9174 len. 16]: This gave me opportunities of being with him that I could not otherwise have had .
Parsing [sent. 9175 len. 29]: And but for his illness he would have been put in irons , for he was regarded as a determined prison-breaker , and I know not what else .
Parsing [sent. 9176 len. 42]: Although I saw him every day , it was for only a short time ; hence , the regularly recurring spaces of our separation were long enough to record on his face any slight changes that occurred in his physical state .
Parsing [sent. 9177 len. 41]: I do not recollect that I once saw any change in it for the better ; he wasted , and became slowly weaker and worse , day by day , from the day when the prison door closed upon him .
Parsing [sent. 9178 len. 19]: The kind of submission or resignation that he showed was that of a man who was tired out .
Parsing [sent. 9179 len. 38]: I sometimes derived an impression , from his manner or from a whispered word or two which escaped him , that he pondered over the question whether he might have been a better man under better circumstances .
Parsing [sent. 9180 len. 24]: But he never justified himself by a hint tending that way , or tried to bend the past out of its eternal shape .
Parsing [sent. 9181 len. 30]: It happened on two or three occasions in my presence , that his desperate reputation was alluded to by one or other of the people in attendance on him .
Parsing [sent. 9182 len. 47]: A smile crossed his face then , and he turned his eyes on me with a trustful look , as if he were confident that I had seen some small redeeming touch in him , even so long ago as when I was a little child .
Parsing [sent. 9183 len. 19]: As to all the rest , he was humble and contrite , and I never knew him complain .
Parsing [sent. 9184 len. 25]: When the Sessions came round , Mr. Jaggers caused an application to be made for the postponement of his trial until the following Sessions .
Parsing [sent. 9185 len. 19]: It was obviously made with the assurance that he could not live so long , and was refused .
Parsing [sent. 9186 len. 24]: The trial came on at once , and , when he was put to the bar , he was seated in a chair .
Parsing [sent. 9187 len. 29]: No objection was made to my getting close to the dock , on the outside of it , and holding the hand that he stretched forth to me .
Parsing [sent. 9188 len. 9]: The trial was very short and very clear .
Parsing [sent. 9189 len. 27]: Such things as could be said for him were said , -- how he had taken to industrious habits , and had thriven lawfully and reputably .
Parsing [sent. 9190 len. 22]: But nothing could unsay the fact that he had returned , and was there in presence of the Judge and Jury .
Parsing [sent. 9191 len. 17]: It was impossible to try him for that , and do otherwise than find him guilty .
Parsing [sent. 9192 len. 43]: At that time , it was the custom -LRB- as I learnt from my terrible experience of that Sessions -RRB- to devote a concluding day to the passing of Sentences , and to make a finishing effect with the Sentence of Death .
Parsing [sent. 9193 len. 42]: But for the indelible picture that my remembrance now holds before me , I could scarcely believe , even as I write these words , that I saw two-and-thirty men and women put before the Judge to receive that sentence together .
Parsing [sent. 9194 len. 21]: Foremost among the two-and-thirty was he ; seated , that he might get breath enough to keep life in him .
Parsing [sent. 9195 len. 36]: The whole scene starts out again in the vivid colors of the moment , down to the drops of April rain on the windows of the court , glittering in the rays of April sun .
Parsing [sent. 9196 len. 50]: Penned in the dock , as I again stood outside it at the corner with his hand in mine , were the two-and-thirty men and women ; some defiant , some stricken with terror , some sobbing and weeping , some covering their faces , some staring gloomily about .
Parsing [sent. 9197 len. 22]: There had been shrieks from among the women convicts ; but they had been stilled , and a hush had succeeded .
Parsing [sent. 9198 len. 46]: The sheriffs with their great chains and nosegays , other civic gewgaws and monsters , criers , ushers , a great gallery full of people , -- a large theatrical audience , -- looked on , as the two-and-thirty and the Judge were solemnly confronted .
Parsing [sent. 9199 len. 6]: Then the Judge addressed them .
Parsing [sent. 9200 len. 73]: Among the wretched creatures before him whom he must single out for special address was one who almost from his infancy had been an offender against the laws ; who , after repeated imprisonments and punishments , had been at length sentenced to exile for a term of years ; and who , under circumstances of great violence and daring , had made his escape and been re-sentenced to exile for life .
Parsing [sent. 9201 len. 37]: That miserable man would seem for a time to have become convinced of his errors , when far removed from the scenes of his old offences , and to have lived a peaceable and honest life .
Parsing [sent. 9202 len. 49]: But in a fatal moment , yielding to those propensities and passions , the indulgence of which had so long rendered him a scourge to society , he had quitted his haven of rest and repentance , and had come back to the country where he was proscribed .
Parsing [sent. 9203 len. 69]: Being here presently denounced , he had for a time succeeded in evading the officers of Justice , but being at length seized while in the act of flight , he had resisted them , and had -- he best knew whether by express design , or in the blindness of his hardihood -- caused the death of his denouncer , to whom his whole career was known .
Parsing [sent. 9204 len. 33]: The appointed punishment for his return to the land that had cast him out , being Death , and his case being this aggravated case , he must prepare himself to Die .
Parsing [sent. 9205 len. 73]: The sun was striking in at the great windows of the court , through the glittering drops of rain upon the glass , and it made a broad shaft of light between the two-and-thirty and the Judge , linking both together , and perhaps reminding some among the audience how both were passing on , with absolute equality , to the greater Judgment that knoweth all things , and can not err .
Parsing [sent. 9206 len. 47]: Rising for a moment , a distinct speck of face in this way of light , the prisoner said , `` My Lord , I have received my sentence of Death from the Almighty , but I bow to yours , '' and sat down again .
Parsing [sent. 9207 len. 20]: There was some hushing , and the Judge went on with what he had to say to the rest .
Parsing [sent. 9208 len. 62]: Then they were all formally doomed , and some of them were supported out , and some of them sauntered out with a haggard look of bravery , and a few nodded to the gallery , and two or three shook hands , and others went out chewing the fragments of herb they had taken from the sweet herbs lying about .
Parsing [sent. 9209 len. 74]: He went last of all , because of having to be helped from his chair , and to go very slowly ; and he held my hand while all the others were removed , and while the audience got up -LRB- putting their dresses right , as they might at church or elsewhere -RRB- , and pointed down at this criminal or at that , and most of all at him and me .
Parsing [sent. 9210 len. 63]: I earnestly hoped and prayed that he might die before the Recorder 's Report was made ; but , in the dread of his lingering on , I began that night to write out a petition to the Home Secretary of State , setting forth my knowledge of him , and how it was that he had come back for my sake .
Parsing [sent. 9211 len. 49]: I wrote it as fervently and pathetically as I could ; and when I had finished it and sent it in , I wrote out other petitions to such men in authority as I hoped were the most merciful , and drew up one to the Crown itself .

Parsing [sent. 9213 len. 37]: And after I had sent them in , I could not keep away from the places where they were , but felt as if they were more hopeful and less desperate when I was near them .

Parsing [sent. 9224 len. 24]: The number of the days had risen to ten , when I saw a greater change in him than I had seen yet .

Parsing [sent. 9263 len. 41]: Chapter LVII Now that I was left wholly to myself , I gave notice of my intention to quit the chambers in the Temple as soon as my tenancy could legally determine , and in the meanwhile to underlet them .
Parsing [sent. 9264 len. 36]: At once I put bills up in the windows ; for , I was in debt , and had scarcely any money , and began to be seriously alarmed by the state of my affairs .
Parsing [sent. 9265 len. 39]: I ought rather to write that I should have been alarmed if I had had energy and concentration enough to help me to the clear perception of any truth beyond the fact that I was falling very ill .
Parsing [sent. 9266 len. 45]: The late stress upon me had enabled me to put off illness , but not to put it away ; I knew that it was coming on me now , and I knew very little else , and was even careless as to that .
Parsing [sent. 9267 len. 45]: For a day or two , I lay on the sofa , or on the floor , -- anywhere , according as I happened to sink down , -- with a heavy head and aching limbs , and no purpose , and no power .
Parsing [sent. 9268 len. 46]: Then there came , one night which appeared of great duration , and which teemed with anxiety and horror ; and when in the morning I tried to sit up in my bed and think of it , I found I could not do so .
Parsing [sent. 9269 len. 178]: Whether I really had been down in Garden Court in the dead of the night , groping about for the boat that I supposed to be there ; whether I had two or three times come to myself on the staircase with great terror , not knowing how I had got out of bed ; whether I had found myself lighting the lamp , possessed by the idea that he was coming up the stairs , and that the lights were blown out ; whether I had been inexpressibly harassed by the distracted talking , laughing , and groaning of some one , and had half suspected those sounds to be of my own making ; whether there had been a closed iron furnace in a dark corner of the room , and a voice had called out , over and over again , that Miss Havisham was consuming within it , -- these were things that I tried to settle with myself and get into some order , as I lay that morning on my bed .

Parsing [sent. 9287 len. 130]: That I had a fever and was avoided , that I suffered greatly , that I often lost my reason , that the time seemed interminable , that I confounded impossible existences with my own identity ; that I was a brick in the house-wall , and yet entreating to be released from the giddy place where the builders had set me ; that I was a steel beam of a vast engine , clashing and whirling over a gulf , and yet that I implored in my own person to have the engine stopped , and my part in it hammered off ; that I passed through these phases of disease , I know of my own remembrance , and did in some sort know at the time .
Parsing [sent. 9288 len. 56]: That I sometimes struggled with real people , in the belief that they were murderers , and that I would all at once comprehend that they meant to do me good , and would then sink exhausted in their arms , and suffer them to lay me down , I also knew at the time .
Parsing [sent. 9289 len. 80]: But , above all , I knew that there was a constant tendency in all these people , -- who , when I was very ill , would present all kinds of extraordinary transformations of the human face , and would be much dilated in size , -- above all , I say , I knew that there was an extraordinary tendency in all these people , sooner or later , to settle down into the likeness of Joe .

Parsing [sent. 9645 len. 62]: Chapter LIX For eleven years , I had not seen Joe nor Biddy with my bodily Eyes , -- though they had both been often before my fancy in the East , -- when , upon an evening in December , an hour or two after dark , I laid my hand softly on the latch of the old kitchen door .
Parsing [sent. 9646 len. 16]: I touched it so softly that I was not heard , and looked in unseen .
Parsing [sent. 9647 len. 59]: There , smoking his pipe in the old place by the kitchen firelight , as hale and as strong as ever , though a little gray , sat Joe ; and there , fenced into the corner with Joe 's leg , and sitting on my own little stool looking at the fire , was -- I again !
